postContent:
I know you want to be the girl-boss and the boss-boss and the pizzaz in the corridors. 

You want your tidy excels and glossy pitch-decks to woo a room full of luminaries. The star employees, the 2x founders, the warriors in the conquest of life. 

And I believe ambition is the wheels to your car, your alloy, your ahoi! It‚Äôll take you from point A to point B, even on days when you‚Äôre a quarter tank. 

BUT..yes, there‚Äôs a but. 

Make it to your friend‚Äôs birthday and your distant cousin‚Äôs wedding. Spend chunky bucks on the dress you want to wear on either of the occasions. 

Please, please attend your child‚Äôs fancy dress and watch them write chronicles on a stage. Talk to your father. Your father is the least expressive and most sensitive man on the face of earth. 

Your aging mother would ask you fifty questions in a row about how to use a Swigit or a Blinky and I recommend you answer all fifty patiently. 

Take yourself on a vacation and wear your ‚ÄúI am saving it for when I am 5 kgs lighter‚Äù outfit. Get chatty with strangers. Listen more. You‚Äôll know how little you really are in this enormous world. 

Do anything but cut open your heart and dysfunction your family and unlove your lover for a job/business/empire. 

I can bet on my life that nobody will remember you for more than how you served them except the ones who love you selflessly. 

I earnestly believe that I am too young to casually throw around this piece of advice on a Sunday afternoon. 

But I‚Äôve seen closely, two of my closest people, inch closer to death for days until they surrendered to it. All they could recall were the faces dear to them, and all I remember about them now is how they lived and loved. 

Live and love fully. Today is the best time to start.

But making people feel something? A small laugh, a single tear, a speck of motivation, a sudden longing for a place they‚Äôve never been to..that‚Äôs rare.

There‚Äôs enough thought-leadership on LinkedIn today. More than enough, honestly. But there‚Äôs very little thought.

Be the thought.

postContent:
I forgot that I have a hugeeee tattoo on my arm.

It‚Äôs something an internet friend once sketched for me after I gave her the vaguest, murkiest description of what I wanted.

It‚Äôs an abstract-ish face of a woman, and from inside her head bloom pansies that cluster into a book. The book endlessly shedding more flowers.

It was meant to remind me that knowledge would be the first reason I‚Äôd ever bloom like a flower. And pansies, they stand for love and affection.

For an eighteen-year-old, I was pretty committed to that thought. It was my 8th tattoo, I think.

But the thing with tattoos is over time, they become you. They stop feeling like a piece of art. Your own skin-painting. They are just‚Ä¶there. 

You scrub them with soap, tan them in the sun, hide them behind sweaters, and forget they even exist.

And then, one day, someone points to it and goes, ‚ÄúOh, you have a tattoo?‚Äù and it takes you a second to remember that you do.

Same with your big glimmery eyes that widen when you talk about something you love. The little mole under your lip. 

The dimple that‚Äôs a crowd-favourite. The way your eyebrows jump when you put the music on. The way your shoulders sway when you dance. 

Even the way you pronounce that one word weirdly, or laugh before finishing your own joke. All your little quirks that you find so easy to forget. 

You live with them every day, so you stop noticing. But they‚Äôre what make you jaw-droppingly beautiful and you‚Äôre an audacious little creature to not acknowledge them. 

For God‚Äôs sake, never forget the tattoo on your arm. And this is really not about tattoos.

postContent:
My grandmother is the most stunning woman I‚Äôve ever known. 

Born in Kashmir and raised in the courtyards of Bhopal, she grew up under the indifferent care of a stepmother who, like the ones immortalized in old bollywood movies, left her with scars that could scarcely be seen on her skin.

I remember when I was sixteen, I was just beginning to love Jane Austen. My grandmother, however, was married off in her sweet sixteen to a man she had never met before. 

She was a mother at seventeen, a mother of two at 25, a mother of 3 at 30. She was fierce, lady-like, significantly talkative. She was the architect of the family I would gladly pierce my heart for.

But I often find myself wondering what might her life had been if the world was kinder. Would she, too, have been enchanted by Austen on a summer evening? 

Would her inquisitive fingers have shot up in a classroom, eager to question, to answer? Would she rather wear a pair of jeans than a patiala salwar? 

She could have been a fashion designer, or perhaps a poet? I know, with cruel certainty, that she would have been remarkable with numbers. All finance bros would squirm in shame. 

Strange, no? A beautiful woman whose course of life has given me a beautiful story of my own. And at the same time, there‚Äôs a little horror in how a brilliance so alive could be subdued by circumstances. 

Anyway, my grandmother is the most stunning woman I have ever known. Wish she could get to know herself better.

postContent:
Some people absolutely hate that our generation is setting boundaries.

Nobody bats an eye now when I discontinue working with a client who doesn‚Äôt respect my time.

But I started freelancing in 2018, back when freelancing wasn‚Äôt as mainstream. Everybody still glorified the grind, still wanted to toil and trade a piece of their flesh for a ‚Äúsecure‚Äù high-paying job.

Now when a 22-year-old respectfully tells their client, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt take calls after 9pm‚Äù or ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not available today‚Äù, a lot of people freak out.

Partly because they‚Äôre unfamiliar with the phenomenon of work-life balance. And partly because Millennials never had this level of autonomy.

Baby Boomers built enormous wealth and passed down favorable conditions to their kids. Millennials, by contrast, started from lower baselines (less inheritance, more debt, costlier housing and education). 

But Gen Z and younger Millennials are doing THE radical (go divas üíÖ) They‚Äôre trading security for agency. They‚Äôre freelancing, they‚Äôre building startups, they‚Äôre studying online, they‚Äôre becoming content creators. 

They know the housing/jobs/education equation has only gotten worse, but they‚Äôre still willing to make that trade-off for freedom, for LIFE. 

Yes, it‚Äôs a privileged stance. Not everyone has the safety net to quit a job or refuse a client when there are bills and families to support. 

But that should make employers and founders even more careful. Because the fastest way to exploit someone is to take advantage of the fact that they can‚Äôt set boundaries.

Freelancers or job-goers, engineers or marketers, young or old - please respect their skill and time.

postContent:
I think most young creatives are disappointed because they were made to believe that they‚Äôll loveeeee their job. 

And sure, writing is a way of living for me. I‚Äôm grateful that I get paid for it. But the worst mistake I‚Äôve committed in some 8 odd years of working is equating my self-worth with writing. 

I love the people I meet through my work. I love that I get to buy another black purse. I love that I can travel around the world. I love that I can pay for my gym membership. 

I love that I can take my mom on a vacation. I love that I can take my boyfriend on date nights. I love that I can buy expensive books. I love that I own a kindle. 

I love that I‚Äôve added 4 ripe avocados to my blinkit cart and my walnuts are soaking in a china cup. I love the colors on my living-room rug. I love that I can buy myself some quality time. 

The sad truth is, I am not changing the world with some viral reels and viral posts and good ads and 10 leads a month. I‚Äôm doing business. And I thoroughly enjoy doing it. 

But I get more creative fulfilment talking about my life here than I do making content calendars. So I‚Äôm not spending another minute romanticising my work-life. I‚Äôm good at it, and it pays the bills. 

Don‚Äôt die or live for your job, guys. Life‚Äôs infinitely bigger than that, and you‚Äôre infinitely more than your skill.

You cooked one meal, ordered two, sat at the cafe alone with your little pink notebook. You spoke to strangers when it terrified you the most. 

You found a job, you quit that job, you found your calling. Now you have days of work and then days of netflixing and it‚Äôs OKAY.

You‚Äôve achieved a lot in life. Now walk like that. And talk like that. And chin up high. üíÖ

postContent:
Enter a boarding gate and you‚Äôll spot an engineer with his Dell backpack, clicking his fifteenth selfie in the same corner. 

Then another on the jetway, and one more by pulling a favour from a stranger near the airstair.

Sunglasses on, then off. Fingers pointing at his collars in that millennial victory-pose. 30 pictures. You can‚Äôt help but smile at his first time.

Walk into a mall and you‚Äôll see an aunty in a chiffon suit hesitating at the escalator. Right foot up, back down, up again. Hands collecting dust from the handrail. 

She‚Äôll pause by a balcony or the food court railing for the perfect shot. Wide smile, wider bindi, bangles clinking in the empty corridor. You can‚Äôt help but smile at her first time.

Step into a big office and you‚Äôll find a nervous girl on her very first day. She fumbles with the coffee machine and settles for whatever comes out first. She hates black.

At lunch, she video-calls her mom to show the office. Bean bags, bright lights, a gym, a nap room. A nap room?! You can‚Äôt help but smile at her first time.

It‚Äôs beautiful, isn‚Äôt it? To witness people living their firsts. It reminds you it hasn‚Äôt been too long since your own, and how foolish it is to forget the privilege of what now feels ordinary.

Here‚Äôs hoping you find your first time today, tomorrow, and again, and again.

Hi! It has been three years on LinkedIn now. 

My name is Shailya. As in shall-yeah. And when I first showed up here, it was with my failures. I perused, got slightly confused, but thoroughly amused to see how crazy this place was. 

Hooks and e-books and virtual fights between writers and their words. So I began to write about myself, and then a little about my work. 

I wrote hooks and canva-ed the hell out of my carousels. I showed up every day at 9:30 AM to offer a little bit of ‚Äògyaan‚Äô. Funny thing is, the wiser you grow, the faster you run out of it. 

I‚Äôve made friends, made enemies, made my place in block-lists for having harsh opinions. But I‚Äôve found a shit load of work here, promoted myself from a freelancer to a business-owner, given my heart some beautiful women (and safe to say I can kill for them). 

I‚Äôve sobbed on all my pillows reading comments, I have screenshots of my dms in an album named ‚Äòlove‚Äô. I have worked with brands that I never thought would work with a lone lancer. I‚Äôve received so much love that my album‚Äôs out of storage space. 

And no, I don‚Äôt do the gyaan anymore. Or the personal-branding tricks or the client-result screenshots or the whatsapp testimonials. I‚Äôm sure that would bring me more ‚Äòleads‚Äô, but I‚Äôm here for whatever leads me to light..

And it‚Äôs always words. Words are all I have and words are all that you‚Äôll see here. They are sad and happy and yellow and grey and sometimes angry but mostly poetic. They‚Äôre all mine. 

Thank you for seeing them, for making time for them, for loving them. These have been three glorious years. ‚ù§Ô∏è

Why do our loves always come wrapped in quotes and unquotes, with a frown here and disdain there when we place them next to something else?

Nahi hu mai ‚Äúcontent creators ke zamane mein lekhak.‚Äù I am a writer. Flawed. Weird. Awkward. Cringe at times.

postContent:
My grandfather left us a bottle of whiskey.

Now, I know what you‚Äôre thinking. No, he didn‚Äôt leave it as our inheritance. Nor did he mean for us to be heavily inebriated to escape the miseries that would unfold after his passing.

My papa was a man who knew nothing but hard work. He bowed down to kiss the ground where his shop stood, and had almost no vices. 

Except that one glass of whiskey he‚Äôd have every Sunday night before bed. Never two, never half, always one full. And he didn‚Äôt drink to get drunk. He truly revelled in its taste (absolute yuck).

One day, my mother was invited to another country for work. Her first international trip after years in corporate. And she knew exactly what to bring back.

For the man who was a little frugal, or rather family-first. The one who usually picked up a Blenders Pride for special occasions, though Officer‚Äôs Choice Blue was an undisputed winner.

Until my mother got him a Black Label. Drum rolls for the Black Label! It was the most expensive bottle he had ever held. And papa being papa, he kept it for when ‚Äúwhoever gets married first; you or your mom.‚Äù

We do that so often, don‚Äôt we? Save the best things for ‚Äòthat day‚Äô. But life is fickle. You never know if you‚Äôll live to see it. So when he was gone, both my mother and I were left with a bottle of whiskey that has now survived three movers and packers.

Over the years, my mother chose singlehood despite my repeated attempts to brainwash her into love again. So the renewed deal was that we‚Äôd open the bottle when I get married.

Again! The same old curse of saving something for ‚Äòthat day‚Äô. But haven‚Äôt we learned our lesson? That good things should be worn, devoured, loved, held, apologised for TODAY? 

Maybe we‚Äôll have a drink on a randomly happy day. When there‚Äôs no particular occasion or milestone to celebrate. On a randomly happy day, we‚Äôll open the 12-year-old Black Label that we‚Äôve kept safe for 9 years now.

Is it a 21-year-old whiskey now? I don‚Äôt know how the aging works for liquor. And even though I don‚Äôt drink as much, and mom can‚Äôt handle more than a half, we‚Äôll have it soon.

postContent:
I‚Äôve been spending a bomb on travelling lately.

I say this while spotting a sparkle of green fireflies again, and watching a frog hop from the bank of river, to me, to the bank again. 

Where we live, there are six dogs, two cats, and a pig. I‚Äôve named it Peppa and so far, it hasn‚Äôt taken offence.

Across the river stands a Buddhist temple, where the only music is the rustling of leaves. The serene-faced bhikkhu cleans the place twice a day.

Nearby, an old lady runs the smallest restaurant I have ever seen. Three tables, one chef, one host, and something tells me both of them have double the hearts.

In one sentence they‚Äôll ask ‚Äúinnum ve·πá·∏çumƒÅ?‚Äù (do you want more?) and before the next, ammaiyar will scrape the juiciest piece of chicken from the bottom of her pot.

Every time you stop for a coffee, a kind man appears with paper and pen, ready to give detailed feedback on your itinerary. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll tell you how to see Sri Lanka, ok?‚Äù beats ‚Äúthis copy is good to go‚Äù any day.

I work from a balcony where five species of birds sing in their own do-re-mi-fa. It has only been two days, and I‚Äôm yet to see more of the country.

Come to think of it, I‚Äôm not spending a bomb after all. I‚Äôm spending too little for what I‚Äôll take away. Travelling is the greatest deal. Literally.

Green fireflies, green! Who knew?

postContent:
I saw this couple in Paris.

Now, it‚Äôs not every day you see a woman in a floral suit, hair parcelled in a neat ghungat, posing before the Eiffel Tower.

But that‚Äôs not the only sight I was marvelling at. It was the man beside her. In ten minutes, uncle had demonstrated fifteen different poses. 

He zoomed in, zoomed out, asked her to rest her delicate, wrinkled fingers on her hip. Then on her ghungat. And each time, he modelled first, so she could see exactly what he meant.

He did nudge her to take the ghungat off for a milisecond. And in rebuttal, she pulled it even closer to her forehead. Smirking. Laughing. Looking around to notice if anyone noticed. 

I glanced around too, expecting to see family. A son, a daughter, maybe grandchildren. But it was just the two of them, still holding hands long after the tower had stopped glimmering, long after most people had hurried off to catch their trains.

I wasn‚Äôt in awe just because I‚Äôd stumbled upon pure love for the first time. God has been kind enough to give me glimpses of it every once in a while. This was something else.

It was the spirit that moved me. The voice on the other end of their video call. The old man navigating a foreign city with one hand holding romance and the other a google map. 

Did their children send them here for their fiftieth anniversary? Or had she once looked at a film and sighed, ‚ÄúKitni sundar jagah hai,‚Äù and he waited until he could make that moment hers?

Maybe that‚Äôs what people mean when they say travel changes your life. Not because the places themselves hold the power to change you. But because they shift the way you see everything you already have.

Gosh am I grateful to have love! And the spirit? I‚Äôll collect whatever I can from moments like these.

postContent:
I‚Äôll tell you a great prompt for writing. 

Unearth your drawer that smells like old ink and forgotten candies to rescue your first plane ticket. Find your friendship bands. Reach out for that book so old that its title wore thin. Stare at the ID card from your first job long enough to know how far you‚Äôve come. Hug your mom. Revisit the song that was once on repeat for every cab ride. Cook a well-balanced meal in the kitchen alone and microwave the garlic before you peel it. Flip through the pages of your diary from 2021 and see if you can find ‚Äúi‚Äôm such a mess‚Äù in bold. Take out the jeans that you‚Äôve been saving for when you lose your flab, toss it away and wear your pajamas. Sit by a big window, or any window. Open the front-camera and try not to look at your pores. Just smile. Smile at the woman who dons a saree for work and is hurriedly scrolling through her office group chat in the elevator. Watch your favourite movie for the 13th time, and then watch one you‚Äôd always skip. Breathe reallyyyy big. Go home with a bag empty and come back with a bag full. Make your bed and tuck the corners real tight. Find a lamp that‚Äôs just right for midnight reading. Learn to love. Love hard. Write about how you wish you could hold your own hand when the plane lands a bit skittish. Dance like everyone‚Äôs watching and you‚Äôre freakishly comfortable being the superstar in your room. On a count of three, drop your phone, prompt less, and think more. 

If you copied this big chunk of text, do you know where you could paste it to produce good writing? Nowhere. So prompt yourself, not the artificially intelligent. Prompt yourself. :)

postContent:
I am not a writer, not just yet. 

I shut my eyes and repeat that thrice before a blank page. Sometimes you can‚Äôt reclaim words because in your head, you‚Äôre ‚Äòthe writer‚Äô. 

You‚Äôre the storyteller, the looked-up-to, the word wizard. But the second you drop this lordly idea of yourself, you come back to a place where writing finds you. 

It finds you in your first breakup, in your unforgiving childhood, in the mourning of your gone grandfather, in your jobless, helpless, and reckless days. 

It finds you in your baby‚Äôs first cry, in your last goodbye from a loveless home, in the moving-on and living-again from a pain you thought will never leave your body. 

Writing comes from your best and worst places. From humility and fragility and scarcity and hopelessness and hopefulness and forgiveness and a few more esses, I guess. 

It comes when you are down bad and down dirty but chin-up and very flirty. It comes as one of the schrodinger‚Äôs cats when you can laugh and cry at the same time. It comes from your best, not necessarily from the best. 

As I write this, I want to be almost-there, almost-good. Because doesn‚Äôt it take an imminent writer to be an eminent writer?

postContent:
What‚Äôs the first thing you do when you wake up? 

I pat-pat every square-inch of the bedside table with my squinting eyes to look for my phone. And you know what I‚Äôve realised? Baby boomers and GenX weren‚Äôt wrong about ‚Äúsaari problem hi phone hai..‚Äù 

Because when I shut my eyes the night before, I wanted to wake up early and read another chapter of the book I‚Äôve been obsessed with. I wanted my Stanley to be half-empty and my yoga mat to be sweaty. 

I wanted to write and write and write till my new client says ‚Äúah this couldn‚Äôt have been better‚Äù. I wanted to water my plants and make chicken-rice for lunch and scribble a poem. 

I did all of that and more. But it‚Äôs no longer enough because my morning scroll revealed that women my age are millionaires already. That biceps and triceps and abs are no longer reserved for men. 

That you ought to have not just protein and fiber and lean carbs, but also the vitamin that I can‚Äôt get myself to spell. And writing? That‚Äôs so yesterday. Today is ChatGPT and you have to catch up. 

My baby steps just don‚Äôt count anymore. I‚Äôve killed all my joy with that morning scroll. I‚Äôve read a hundred success announcements and picked zero knowledge. What a bummer! 

You see, most people on the internet don‚Äôt want to make you happy. They want to make you WANT to be happy. If they could make you happy, they‚Äôd have nothing to sell. 

Do yourself a favour and don‚Äôt be a killjoy. Skip that morning scroll, or perhaps filter it. That‚Äôs what I did this morning and I‚Äôm the happiest person on earth (at least for today). 

Today is what matters, right?

postContent:
Mid-twenties come with this awful feeling of not having done enough. 

I could have read books from authors unpopular or known, I could have travelled to a faraway city alone. 

I could have rented an apartment of my own and hung my dog‚Äôs painting on the wall, there‚Äôs so much money in the world I could have bagged it all. 

I could have climbed a mountain or a wall or the ladder of fame, I could have been a mukbanger, an asmr-ist, an e-girl influencer, or is that lame? 

I could have at least fallen in love or learned how to swim, how hard could it have been to move to another country on a whim? 

‚ÄúI have wasted my golden years‚Äù, but sweets, have you really?  It‚Äôs too soon to say so. You‚Äôve only been a little bit silly. 

Does it ever happen to you that you‚Äôre reading a chapter in a book and your thoughts are led astray? Eyes in a straight line, but mind a lil gay? 

Then you flip the pages, go back to the first word, and this time you swear to read with your heart. Life also begins from wherever you want to start. 

You‚Äôre quarter-way through the book, three quarters to go before you sit and drat. And YOU decide where this story goes, how amazing is that?!

postContent:
Not all kids want to be their parents. 

Every time someone gave me a scrap-book to fill, I‚Äôd write my mother‚Äôs name in chicken scratch under ‚Äòyour role model‚Äô. 

I dressed up like her, I spoke like her, heck I even wanted to fit into her shoes at four. And now that I‚Äôm old enough to bump shoulders with her, I‚Äôm still a lot like my mom. And a lot like myself. 

But my friend, now racing up the corporate ladder, goes to visit her parents only twice a year. Not because she has run out of love. Because she is running away from what her parents were (or are). 

And I‚Äôve come across many like her. Children who leave home and never look back. Young adults who empty their bottles of scotch to live better for their better halves. 

Ladies who keep their rage to themselves and gentlemen who mind their hands. They walk into therapy so that their kids don‚Äôt have to live with the clanking of childhood memories. 

You might think that you‚Äôd never escape this biological hellhole and somehow end up just like your mother/father. You won‚Äôt. 

Science can argue with its theories but I‚Äôve seen people escape. And some, I‚Äôve seen very closely. To them I want to say that you‚Äôre nothing like your broken parent. 

You‚Äôre your own person. A beautiful one at that.

postContent:
There‚Äôs this awkward phase in adulting that you don‚Äôt quite understand at first. 

I mean, be honest. Did you truly know what acidity is when you‚Äôd hasten to the college canteen and pick everything deep-fried, with no deep regrets? 

Did you know that cardio is not strength-building when you danced at a party for 5 hours straight and woke up with a fully functional back? 

Did you really know how much water could solve for? And that one day you‚Äôll be squirming by a food court for your arhar ki daal aur chaawal with mirchi ka achaar? 

Did you really know that marksheets and friendship-feuds will look petty when all you‚Äôre worried about is your parents getting old and the house getting smaller? 

I was such a life-of-the-party person, you know. Jesus couldn‚Äôt get me to stay in on a Friday night for the love of humanity. And this is what my evening looked like yesterday. 

Dried-out paint, teek-mahogany candle, rhythm and blues, and we made some kickass oil-free skinless tandoori chicken.

postContent:
I love to see men cry. 

No, neither am I sadistic nor fettered by misandry. There‚Äôs something beautiful about the rebellion against this strong-men-shed-no-tears propaganda. 

Boyfriends weeping outside the airport after having picked her favourite kind of flowers. Husbands sobbing rains on their wedding night. 

Papas holding their glasses out of the way in a fatherly fashion and wiping droplets clean before they trickle down their dense moustaches..

If I were born a man, I‚Äôd be a serious sobber. Because the grandpa who helped raise me would break into fat tears on ‚Äúbabul ki duaayein leti jaa..‚Äù (a vidaai song) when I was aged 7 and decades away from my wedding day. 

That‚Äôs how comfortable he was with his fragility. That‚Äôs how healthy masculinity looks like. When you don‚Äôt bundle up and bog down and keep a straight face when life is everything but a straight line. 

I have guy friends I have never seen cry, and a guard bhaiya who won‚Äôt budge while narrating the most gut-wrenching story I have ever heard. I have co-workers going through the roughest breakups and their peers aren‚Äôt fully aware of it. 

It‚Äôs a sad truth. Men don‚Äôt voice their woes. They don‚Äôt melt away with their bros. Perhaps in the fear of weakening their loved ones, or in the pursuit of weakening themselves? 

If there‚Äôs an ultimate display of strength when the going gets tough, it‚Äôs the tough being able to cry about it. And maybe that‚Äôs why I love to see men cry. Strong men cry and let it all out and shimmy and shine ‚ú®

There was a time when I loved writing on LinkedIn. 

I wrote about my Sundays, my colossal failures, my imaginary dog, my classmate from 4th standard who gave me a lesson on humility. 

LinkedIn made me jealous. Jealous of writers who could easily pen their entire lives down, easy as pie! 

I wanted to be them, I wanted to throw up stories. I wanted to make people laugh and cry and giggle on a Monday afternoon. 

And sometimes I‚Äôd stumble upon a gem in a stranger‚Äôs comment section. Believe it or not, AI-generated comments weren‚Äôt an option back then. 

I hateeeee to say this, but I‚Äôm tired. I‚Äôm tired of what works here. I‚Äôm tired of hooks and baseless corporate jokes and empty writing. 

I‚Äôll stick around because I owe it to people who‚Äôve given me this platform, who‚Äôve made me what I am here. A friend to them. 

But on most days, it feels like a chore. For heaven‚Äôs sake, bring LinkedIn back. Make mistakes. The last thing I want to know on LinkedIn is how to grow on LinkedIn. 

I get it, the algorithm gives more weight to ‚Äúrelevant posts‚Äù. But I fail to understand what‚Äôs more relevant from a writer than honest writing.

postContent:
Freelancing comes with a lot of loneliness. 
And a job comes with some heavy, heavy bags. 

Vacations come with lost luggage, visa rejections, cancelled flights, and last-minute chums. 

A rented pad of your own comes with a week‚Äôs worth of unwashed laundry and dusty corners. 

A foreign degree comes with frozen parathas and frozen video-calls and frozen hearts. 

Maa ke hath ka khana comes with a rejected leave application, and the fruits at home come with a hint of her garlicky knife. 

Love comes with a little bickering and patiently collecting the broken pieces of your soulmate. 

Strength comes with sore legs and sorer arms and reluctantly replacing your sugar with dates. 

You see, when good things make a reservation in your life, they need space. They need you to scoot and bet and break a sweat. 

They‚Äôll sit with you for a rehearsal dinner and maybe even make you sob a little. 

You might not always write them down but they need your vows. They need your will and your prayer. 

They need some air, and then a thank-you. They‚Äôll wait at the doorstep, but never prank you. 

These good things, I tell you. They‚Äôre always making sure whether they truly belong.

 A mom juggling her 9-5, home, and a child gets less applause than an influencer who has stolen her hard-earned title. ‚ÄúMother‚Äù, we call her.

And why, for the love of God, are we worshipping internet faces? Call me a snob, but I‚Äôm just not inspired by 99% of the famous people today.

Not posting on LinkedIn makes me anxious. There, I said it!

postContent:
Be your own duck. 
I know that‚Äôs an absurd advice for a Saturday, but hear me out. 

I was the person who could get lost if left two miles away from home. ‚ÄòDirectionally challenged‚Äô or ‚ÄòSpatially Unaware‚Äô or ‚ÄòPrincessly Passenger‚Äô - I‚Äôd give myself the names I liked the most. 

I was convinced that it‚Äôs easy for me to get lost. That I struggle finding my way back home. That I can‚Äôt go to the movies alone and come back unworried. 

My partner calls me a duckling. I love shutting my brain cells and letting him fiddle with the maps and apps. But you know what he also says very often? 

‚ÄúI love that you‚Äôre my duckling, but I also know that if you were here alone, you‚Äôd navigate the shit out of this world. Because you‚Äôre that person. You‚Äôre fearless. You‚Äôre the duck too.‚Äù 

And he was absolutely right. Because I‚Äôve loved nothing more than finding my way back in a foreign land. Of course, I love being the duckling every once in a while, but that‚Äôs by choice, not by nature. 

Financial independence is great. But the freedom of movement, the tapping into your unexplored dora-the-explorer - it gives you so much power. 

So..be your own duck. Waddle, flap, paddle, fly.You‚Äôll love every bit of it.

postContent:
It‚Äôs mama‚Äôs first REAL vacation in 20 goddamn years! 

You know how mothers are. They see less of the world because they chose to see more world in you. Or was it really a choice? 
 Her desires are packed away in steel trunks somewhere under the bed, behind the panic, next to the winter quilts.

So when mine said, almost shyly, ‚ÄúI want to see Europe with my daughter‚Äù, it took me a second of contemplation to book everything. 

We got our visas. We fell sick five days before the flight. Cancelled everything. Told ourselves it wasn‚Äôt meant to be.

I gave it another shot and rebooked it all. And then, 12 hours before the flight, the airline cancelled.

I won‚Äôt bore you with the chaos that followed.But somehow, we fought the universe for it and we made it.

And I‚Äôm so, so glad we did.
Because there is something unexplainably beautiful about watching your mother live the dreams she never got the time to dream.
 So..hi from Zurich guyssss ü•∞ We‚Äôre LOSING our minds it‚Äôs so beautiful here. Anyone who wasn‚Äôt born into money would know how unreal a europe trip feels. 

And I hope one day, you get to take your mother on her dream vacation too. Even if she never calls it that.

postContent:
Fatherhood is something I‚Äôve witnessed briefly. 

In bits and pieces. In borrowed days.
In the way my nana taught me how to tie a tie, and to this day, I can do it with my eyes closed.

In the way my mother slipped into the role on weekends, teaching me how to cycle, skate, and ride a scooter without crashing into two things at once.

In the way my best friend‚Äôs dad always brought home ice creams and sparkles for two. Those were the best kind of sleepovers.

I think I‚Äôm now too old to feel that aching of ‚ÄúAh, I wish I had that,‚Äù But still young enough to look at fatherhood with absolute awe and curiosity. 

And maybe that‚Äôs exactly why I love Father‚Äôs Day.

Because I get to live vicariously through you.Through your stories. Through the daddy‚Äôs little girls who still remain little at 50. Through the super dads here. 

Happy Father‚Äôs Day to me, to my beautiful mom,and to all of you.

postContent:
Storytellers, are we?

We, the writers. The philosophers of the feed. The speculators and opportunists. 

We mean to stir the stillness in people, shake the ashes off their lives, remind them how short it all is.

But some stories are not yours to tell.

They belong to a daughter who hasn‚Äôt yet stood up straight.
To a mother still changing the sheets on a bed that won‚Äôt be slept in.
To a friend who hasn‚Äôt said it out loud.
To a man who hasn‚Äôt cried yet.

You want to write something?
Write about your silence.
Write about your helplessness.
Do us a favour and write nothing at all. 

Because grief, and real grief, takes time to even find its name. And the stories you‚Äôre trying to tell?
They aren‚Äôt even stories yet. They‚Äôre just pain. 

If there‚Äôs one LinkedIn lesson you‚Äôre looking for today, let it be on holding space and silence for things that aren‚Äôt yours.

postContent:
Growing up in a middle class family, the soup always came ‚Äòone in two‚Äô. 

A tissue paper was beat hollow with the mouth-freshener, and then carefully tucked in pockets. 

One petite glass of tuity-fruity took multiple rotations until the last cherry went to the youngest in the house. 

Uniforms always hung loose on the shoulders because it was meant to last 3 years, sometimes even passed on. 

Now that I‚Äôve been promoted to a higher social class (which takes half luck and half work in this economy), I meet people who only want more.

Sharing is such an alien concept today, no? We want it all to ourselves. Owing to the hyper-independence that reeks of loneliness. 

And often, you will feel smart about having it all to yourself. You‚Äôll live in the illusion of wealth. You‚Äôll feel rich. 

But the truth is, nothing multiplies or makes you happy if it‚Äôs all yours. Not your time, not your wealth, not your love, not your knowledge. 

You can gatekeep your wisdom, hide your dollars from the loved ones, save two pennies by sweet-talking an innocent man, get stingy with love.. 

But one in two for me, please. Any day.

Did you know that awards can be bought?

That your role model will write a whole paragraph on body-positivity and cry alone looking at her love handles?

postContent:
Pride Month feels quiet this year, doesn‚Äôt it?Allow me to tell you a story.

I knew this virtual friend from Instagram. A 27-year-old engineer. Tall, dark, handsome, and oddly invested in my outfit details.
 I once told him where I got my heels from, and a week later, he ordered the same pair.

One day, out of nowhere, I got a photo of him wearing a silk-green skirt and those heels.With a message that said ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt told anyone, but I‚Äôve always felt more like a girl.‚Äù

It took me aback. Takes a minute and a half to truly understand people. But you know how girls‚Äô girls are, right?
 They drop a ‚Äúyesss queen, you slaayyy, you set my phone on fire‚Äù in the comments.I did the same. For her.

Her close friends and I got an exclusive sneak peek into all her looks. Sometimes even the dates. But her family and friends? Completely unaware.

Until one day, she decided to put her heels down and come out. You‚Äôd hope the world to be all cotton candy and rainbows. But some things are hard to explain. Harder to accept.

It‚Äôs been two years since she last saw her parents. There was loud acceptance of their highly educated engineer son with the great job.

But an engineer daughter who got promoted, is half an artist, and has incredible taste in skirts?Not really.

And hers isn‚Äôt the only broken family I‚Äôve seen.There are many. I don‚Äôt paint my face or wave flags this month.
 But I do, earnestly, hope for acceptance and forgiveness. Acceptance from parents who still struggle to understand their children. Forgiveness from children whose parents once turned away and now try to embrace them.

I pray the broken families are mended.I pray.

postContent:
I remember a scribble in one of my old diaries.
‚ÄúMy body is a temple.‚Äù

But for the past 2 months, this temple has had a few disturbances. I was sick almost every other week. 

Nothing major. Just enough to throw me off rhythm. I gave five blood tests last month. Five.

And still, every report came back clear. Not one thing wrong. It‚Äôs like my body kept saying, ‚ÄúHey, I‚Äôm not at my best, but I‚Äôm still here. I‚Äôve got you.‚Äù

Ah! My temple. It loves me. To be almost sick but never let me fall entirely. To carry me gently through the mess.

I wondered if I was loving it back as much. No movement. No dance. No strength training.
My pink dumbbells now carry abandonement issues. 

So I made a quiet promise to myself. That if my body is still fighting for me, I‚Äôll fight for it too.

My partner and I started with small treks. Nothing crazy, just something to get the rhythm back.

It‚Äôs 10:24 AM on the 20th of May. In the last 3 days, I‚Äôve done 50k steps. Steeeeeeeep ones. 

I was out of breath, out of practice, but we did it.

And now I know.
My body is indeed a temple.
And it‚Äôs time I start restoring the pillars.

postContent:
Yesterday, I met a 20-year-old who was nearly in tears over her career.

She kept saying she felt lost. That her friends had it all figured out. One had even started a company and buzz-worded her linkedin bio. She, meanwhile, was circling the same questions over and over again. 

I listened quietly. Because I remember being her. And I can swear on my first penny-pinching handbag, no 20-year-old would be helped if you told them ‚Äúit‚Äôs too soon to worry‚Äù. It‚Äôs always too soon in your world, too late in someone else‚Äôs & vice versa. 

Everybody wants to ‚Äúcrack it‚Äù, you know. But you don‚Äôt crack your way into something. You crack your way through it. Through confusion. Through doubt. Through donothingery. 

Whenever you meet this young timid person, don‚Äôt tell them they‚Äôre too young to worry. They won‚Äôt listen. Tell them about all the good books you‚Äôve read, tell them about the good people you‚Äôve met. 

Tell them what made you pee your pants with excitement when you were 20. Tell them what matters NOW, 5 or 10 or 15 or 20 years later so that they know there‚Äôs sooooooo much more yet to know. Not to crack, just to know. 

Tell them about your first girlfriend and your first trip and why you wrote your first resignation letter. Tell them about your good bosses and bad bosses and huge losses. 

Tell them that you‚Äôre smiling today not because you have all the answers, but because you now know that not having answers wasn‚Äôt a problem. It was the beginning.

postContent:
There‚Äôs only one superhero I‚Äôve ever believed in.

Not the ones in capes, or the ones who leap off buildings, or save cities before breakfast. Mine wore a lot of courage walked out the door when I was just about learning to walk.

I was a year old when she went job-hunting to become the sole bread-winner of the family. And in the same year, she was a wife, and then a mother, and then a divorcee. But the only role she chose fiercely, wholly, and without pause, was that of a mother.

So she did what no one had taught her to do. She began again. Her first job was transcribing medical records, her second was in a call centre.And while most people spent years waiting for promotions that never came,
 she walked up to her boss one day and said,‚ÄúI have a daughter. I can‚Äôt sit in this cubicle pulling night shifts. I can‚Äôt be in tele sales forever. I want a career. Give me something to grow into.‚Äù

And just like that, she never stopped growing. She moved cubicles and cities and offices. From a shared hostel to a stuffy PG, from a dingy BK to a sunlit BHK, and now we live in a home that finally feels like it has room for all the dreams she once postponed.

I‚Äôve never really understood the fuss around superheroes. They‚Äôve always seemed a little too shiny, a little too far away. Mine was here, right in-front of me, being a mother, a daughter, a sister, an empathetic boss, a problem solver, a birthday-rememberer, a tear-wiper - all at once.

If I could‚Äôve gone to fancy dress day dressed like her, I would have. And I almost did. Because the only superhero I believe in is my mama. And I am because she is.

postContent:
My friend has aged parents in Amritsar. Not a blink of an eye, not a peaceful slumber. He‚Äôs calling home every hour. 

Peers in Jammu have met an unfamiliar face of fear. You can only imagine how the heart sinks when missiles come your way at the pace of a shooting star. 

And while talking to a loved one in Kashmir, I asked him to survive this for heaven‚Äôs sake. ‚ÄúThis time, it‚Äôs not upto me‚Äù, he retorted. 

You get to sit in your air-conditioned room, still go to work, still post 10 tips to grow on LinkedIn, still go about your day, and say ‚Äúwe shall fight and win this war‚Äù? 

You and your illusory patriotism can exit the room and shut the door behind you. If you want to fight, fight your urge of running your relentless fingers on the keyboard. Park your celebration and show some empathy. 

Nobody wishes for war, but now we‚Äôre here. There‚Äôs going to be loss of life and chaos and indelible scars and broken families. Your celebration is not helping. 

I understand that restoring peace, starting a revolution, it comes with a heavy human cost. But try not saying that to someone who‚Äôs hearing sirens all day. They don‚Äôt need to be reminded of the price. They‚Äôre already paying it.

postContent:
There‚Äôs always space for the misfits. 

Between our ceramic and bohemian plates, lays a collection of 90‚Äôs floral bone china, or famously known as ‚Äúguests aayein toh nikalna‚Äù crockery. 

And while shuffling between the beige and white, the abstract and contemporary, we quietly sneak in a decade-old bedsheet that adorns biologically absent flowers in all colors known to mankind. 

A stone pestle and mortar that have been passed on to four generations now, looks at our multi-functional mixer, grinder, juicer, and smoothie-maker in utter scepticism. 

And the steel masala daani may have been replaced with dainty glass jars, but a tin chocolate box still sits somewhere in the house, safe-guarding threads that are now as precarious as situationships. 

I‚Äôve lived in 5 homes in the past 25 years, and no matter where I went, I carried a hundred little things that witnessed my adolescence. The they-don‚Äôt-belong-here things. The beautiful things. The misfits. 

And for myself, I‚Äôve preserved these misfits in traits. A louder-than-necessary laughter in a formally quiet room. The ketchup-song dance wherever the song plays, however reserved the setting. 

I safekeep the child-like hop in my walk, the unapologetic giggle, the Uttar Pradesh dialect occasionally slipping through my carefully chosen vocabulary. The little things that may not go well with the rest of me, but they make me. 

The beautiful things. The silly things. The misfits.

postContent:
It‚Äôs okay to admit that you‚Äôre just..okay. 
Not broken, not thriving, just somewhere in between. 

That you woke up before your alarm and brushed your teeth and had one healthy meal and took a walk and got halfway through your to-do list. 

Sure, there is no appreciation for the in-betweens. No sympathy for ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just..here.‚Äù No advice for ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs wrong, because nothing really is.‚Äù 

But you know what? I‚Äôm glad you‚Äôre here. I‚Äôm glad you‚Äôre just okay. It takes a hell lot to be. :)

postContent:
In 2006, a deadly fire broke out in Meerut. 

I spent 15 years of my life in that town. My mom, always the busy boss lady, walked in heels, spoke in bullet points, and took calls like her phone was an extension of her hand. But no matter how important the meeting, she never missed our mommy-daughter dates.

One of those dates was at Victoria Park, during a consumer electronics fair. From what I remember, it was a good date. But the next morning, everything changed.

Relatives who hadn‚Äôt called in years were suddenly calling, frantically. A huge fire had broken out at that same fair. 65 dead. 150 injured. The attendance had been over 2,000, a staggering number for a small town like Meerut.

One of the victims was a girl from my tuition class. We weren't close, but I knew her. She used to tap her pen against the table when she was bored. She‚Äôd been absent for weeks. And when she finally returned, she was quiet in a way children shouldn't be.

Her entire left arm had third-degree burns.
She always wore long sleeves after that. Pulled them down every time they threatened to reveal anything. Sat smaller. Spoke less. Moved carefully. 

I won‚Äôt lie and say no one noticed. Kids always notice. For a long time, she was the girl who burnt her left arm, even if nobody said that out loud. 

As days went by, she began to care less. Stopped hiding the arm. Raised it in class. High-fived with it. Joined us for tippy tippy tap during break time. And slowly, I stopped seeing the scar too. 

I saw her eyes light up when she talked about acrylic paints. I noticed the bright pink of her top. The pretty pencil box she had - one of those with buttons that popped open compartments like magic. She was kind. Funny. Braver than all of us combined. And yes, maybe a little rich too, we all envied that pencil box! 

Over time, her scar stopped being the thing that defined her. The scar became her, not the other way round. You know how broken glass still catches light? She was all light. She was sparkle, she was beautiful. 

And that‚Äôs what I want to tell you. You, carrying things no one else can see. You, who flinch when someone touches a part of your story.

You are everything but your scars.And everything because of them, too.

postContent:
Am I a fool? 

One of my posts blew up beyond the linkedin galaxy. It was on the news, on Instagram, on Threads, on Reddit. I swear on my sweetest poem, I didn‚Äôt see that coming. 

And predictably, a few brands reached out to me for collaboration. I thought, quite a lot, and politely said no. But a part of me wondered if I was too irrational, too righteous, too haughty, too i‚Äôm-not-an-influencer-i‚Äôm-a-writer kind? 

It‚Äôs not to say that there‚Äôs something wrong about being an influencer, or that writers don‚Äôt sell. We make you believe that you‚Äôll never fly if it weren‚Äôt for an energy drink. 

But there‚Äôs a pretty girl here who once said she‚Äôd want an elder sister like me, would it be fair to elicit a desire in her for a thing she can do without? 

And then there‚Äôs a young writer, fresh out of school, who told me our lives are the same. Do I now become the ad she can‚Äôt skip within 5 seconds to jump to her story time?

I‚Äôm ridden with the curse of over-consumption. 5 lipbalms, a moisturiser for the day and then one for after noon, 15th version of the same goddamn jeans, a shampoo 10 times the price of a shampoo. I‚Äôve caved in. I‚Äôve fallen prey. Do I carry out the hunt now? 

I‚Äôm sorry if this is poking the marketer or founder or influencer in you. It poked me too. But isn‚Äôt it true? Isn‚Äôt this what we do? 

Yes, I do write for some of these brands. I have bills to pay, a pocket to fill. If I don‚Äôt write that headline, someone else will. But here? It‚Äôs all me. It‚Äôs my prose and my woes and ups and hiccups and downs and frowns. It‚Äôs all me. 

Here, nobody can tell my story better. So, pray tell! Am I a fool if I just want to..be? If you feel otherwise, please enlighten me?

postContent:
Yes, not all men! But if only you knew how many women..

I was once in a room with four, far away from home. A hostel is a place where solo travel ends, because you only have to meet eyes once or help someone settle in their bunk before you become friends. 

So me, and my four new friends sat in a circle with our adult beverages and talked about it. We mutually agreed that not all men. But how many women? 

All four raised hands, and then I, the fifth. While one‚Äôs abuser was a close relative, the other was persecuted by her own partner. I remember we weeped a little when a girl narrated an abominable interaction with her own father. Her father. 

And even though all of us were terrified, heartbroken, shook, tired, we looked at each other as if we were there to reclaim freedom. To reclaim days and nights and moments and joys and love. 

To go on post-dinner walks without scanning danger in faces, to sit in a cab without tracing the maps, to walk into a boardroom and actually be heard, to make a friend fearlessly, to not overthink our dresses five times before we leave home. 

We hugged, we smiled, we laughed, we went to a party in a group of five and danced like nobody was watching. But alas! Everybody was watching. 

So yes, I‚Äôm in agreement. Not all men. But if only you knew how many women..

postContent:
You deserve more.

These three words come second only to ‚ÄúI love you‚Äù in a more platonic, you‚Äôve-got-my-vote kind of way. But they always confused me.

What do I deserve more of? Recognition? Work? Money? Vacations? Rest? Peace? Joy?

If they‚Äôre all the result of each other, do I deserve more of everything? 

To find answers, I started chasing more. More validation, more projects, more savings, more holidays, more nap hours, more writing, more writing again.

But every time I got more of one thing, another quietly slipped away. If not entirely, then at least a little.
 You know when you want more money to visit Italy in the summer, but to earn more money, you're stuck in your work chair with Uffizi Galleries on your desktop? 

It took me a while to understand what people mean when they say more. 

My best friend sends me flowers every time I bag a new client. My boyfriend takes me out for dinner on my worst writing days.
 My mother likes everything I write. Everything. Isn‚Äôt that ridiculously beautiful? And then there‚Äôs you. Some of you have been around for three years now and you still show up to say,
 ‚ÄúYou deserve more.‚Äù

And that...That is my more.The people who wish more for me.

I‚Äôve said this before, and I‚Äôll say it again. Writing to me comes close to worshipping, I wouldn't do it to mislead. Never have I been open to paid promotions. This was a genuine mishap salvaged by great people. 

The virality, however, did lead people to my writing (which I‚Äôve been doing here for 3 odd years now). I have new clients to attend to and hot leads to nurture, all thanks to you.

postContent:
Ye shaam mastani, madhosh kiye jaaye. 

When I was little, my mom would listen to the saddest songs ever made. Mohammad Rafi, Lata Mangeshkar, Abida Parveen. Songs that were cried more than they were sung. 

At the time, it was just hauntingly beautiful music with a little gibberish to me. But years later, I realised it mirrored my mother‚Äôs sorrow. She took refuge in those voices.

We spent years at my grandparents‚Äô home. And then a decade in and out of rented apartments. Just the two of us. Two best friends, tossing our days and nights into a cardboard box marked ‚Äòfragile.‚Äô

We were indeed fragile. In the most regenerative way possible. We knew how to steal joy from the tougher times. But having our own place? Our arms were always shy of miles to reach that dream.

You know when the universe is in agreement and sends a bit of luck to accompany you? Just when you‚Äôve had nothing more, nothing less, but enoughhhh? I believe that‚Äôs what happened with us. We were suddenly sharing a room with luck. 

And one day, we found ourselves in a partially broken home that was all ours. Our home. Our home. Our home. (1.5 years later, it‚Äôs as hard to say and believe). 

Every time we came here to knock the POP and critique the paint and measure the bar, we‚Äôd cry our eyes out. In utter disbelief, in gratitude, in pain, in devotion. 

We‚Äôd debate about what carpet would match the sofas, and then watch each other turn green. There‚Äôs something sweetly terrifying about dreams coming true, and we weren‚Äôt privy to this fear. Because none of ours had ever come true. 

But the last time we sat in our undone living room, we decided to switch things up. We packed a shit load of my world-famous maggi and some coke. Laid a bedsheet on gravel and stones and took it all in.

And then I heard the song - Ye shaam mastani, madhosh kiye jaaye. On my mother‚Äôs phone. ‚ÄúDid I just hear a happy song, our first happy song together?, I bellowed out. 

And that‚Äôs what I wish for whoever‚Äôs reading this. I wish you nothing less than a whole playlist of happy songs.

postContent:
Some nights, I sleep with my bedside lamp on.

Not because I‚Äôm scared or I believe that there‚Äôs a town underneath my bed, inhabited by monsters. 

Because it‚Äôs strange how silence changes after midnight. It doesn‚Äôt hum, it presses. 

It reminds you of every conversation you didn‚Äôt have, every version of yourself you left unread. 

You‚Äôd think with time, it‚Äôd get easier.
The knowing. The becoming. The being.
But some parts of growing up aren‚Äôt pretty.

They‚Äôre quiet.
And confusing.
And a little lonely.

No one warns you that healing doesn‚Äôt always feel good. It feels like boredom. Or guilt. Or an overwhelming desire to rearrange your wardrobe. And yet, we do it anyway.
 We show up.
We write bad. 
We journal silly. 
We eat rolled oats.We fold the laundry.We return the client calls.
We tidy the mess in our dumping-drawer. We water the plants we almost gave up on.

Some days, that‚Äôs all healing is.A little light.Left on.In case hope wants to stop by.

postContent:
If you‚Äôre in your 20s, take my word for it and travel more. 

It doesn‚Äôt have to be La Dolce Vita and bouncy hotel beds. From what I remember, I once shared a bathroom with 15 surprisingly hygienic millennials and took the topmost bunk bed of my own freewill. 

Enter a restaurant alone and sit on a round table. You wouldn‚Äôt want to, but get yourself a big meal. Not a quickie sandwich you can grab and rush out so that people never learn that you‚Äôre alone. BIG meal. And chew exactly 32 times on each bite. 

Try their local food. Like it or hate it, but try it. And if you‚Äôre in an unknown land, I‚Äôd recommend keeping hot-sauce in your fanny at all times. 

Be terribly scared and anxious, if you are. To find  the immigration queue or your bus stop or the train route that leads to your bnb. But in about a day‚Äôs time, you‚Äôll throw bouquets and croissants at your own audacity. You‚Äôll walk taller. Perhaps not on a cobble street of a 60-degree incline, but you‚Äôll be proud. 

Talk to people in their language and watch a smile touch their ears from left to right. And at least a hundred times in your life, pluck a fruit from an actual tree and eat it in the sun. Not in the shade, in the sun. It‚Äôll make you realise just how little you are in this big world, and how important you‚Äôve mistaken trivial things to be. 

Clutch your purse to your heart and pray that nobody steals it, you‚Äôll learn caution. Wake up at 5am for the sunrise while everyone else is laying hungover, you‚Äôll never settle for less. Trek till the top of any tiny or ginormous hill, you‚Äôll never fear uncertainty. 

Nothing changes you like travelling. As someone whose workplace is also their home, I have to find my world outside my four walls. I have to go places when I‚Äôm the most afraid to. And while being alone back at home is suffocating, being alone outside in the big world is more freeing than you can imagine. 

I‚Äôm really not the one to give advice. I‚Äôm a learner at heart, and shall always be one. But if you‚Äôre in your 20s and reading this, take my word for it and travel more.

postContent:
The uncomfortable conversations. 

I never told my mom that I had an ill-tempered, descendant of King-John, barely sapien of a boyfriend until I turned 20. And I never told my bestfriend that I was sick of being her speed-dial when she had a favour to pull. In all honesty, it only needed a quick grab, not necessarily a pull,  because favours would just spring out of me. 

It‚Äôs hard, no? To tell a colleague that most of your smiles are fake. To talk to your teenager about sex and drugs and young romance. To tell a sibling that they absolutely sucked at being the elder one. To tell your partner that they need to stop reminding you how small your problems are. 

You could have the memory of a 2 year old and still remember how people made you feel. Because thank-effing-goodness, feelings aren‚Äôt facts. They leave a load on your chest. And it‚Äôs as hard to confront your feelings as it is to confront the person who caused them. 

Withholding is a terrible curse, and I spoke myself out of it quite recently. I refuse to be politically correct, readily available, internally a clustershit and externally the telly-tubby‚Äôs sun with a laughing baby face on it. 

Withholding makes you pretend, it makes you smile when you don‚Äôt want to, it makes you say ‚Äòyes‚Äô for the 100th time that you‚Äôve wanted to say ‚Äòno‚Äô. It makes your loved ones clueless and your younger ones great liars. It‚Äôs harmful for your heart, and the bees. It‚Äôs killing the bees (or is it phones that are?). 

If you‚Äôre planning to do yourself and the people you care about a favour, let it be an uncomfortable conversation.

postContent:
What happened to making silly mistakes? 

I don‚Äôt know if ChatGPT is out to get your jobs yet, but it‚Äôs definitely keeping young writers from the beautifully chaotic process of writing. 

I miss that misfit of a phrase sitting in the middle of a post, an aimless comparison of your heartbreak to the unkept bedside table. The messy writing, the diary writing, the screaming-at-a-blank-screen writing. I miss all of it. 

I‚Äôve been noticing a certain sameness in the content here. And it breaks my heart to know that writers who are perfectly capable of telling their own stories are so heavily dependent on AI. 

Sure, it‚Äôs meant to make your life easier, but only when you‚Äôre good at what you do. You were not meant to write good prompts. You were meant to write good. You were meant to make mistakes. You were meant to look at your poem and think ‚Äúurgh, it‚Äôs not quite there yet.‚Äù 

Writing takes some heavy brain-exercise. Play with words, twist a sentence to extreme madness, draw parallels between a watermelon and your life, give a whole new meaning to the most overused word in the world‚Äôs dictionary. That‚Äôs the beautiful chaos. 

For some, it‚Äôs too soon to make things easy. I say, make things hard. Think. Challenge that thinking. Make silly mistakes, please.

postContent:
One bitter-sweet part of adulthood is role-reversal. 

Growing up, I watched my mother become twice a parent. Both nani and I would enter a doctor‚Äôs clinic nervously tapping our feet on the marble floor, while mom knew exactly where to go. 

She‚Äôd hug us the same, as if she wanted to clasp our years, freeze the time. She would still keep the clothes I had outgrown, collect my hairclips in an empty chocolate box. And every time she caressed her mother‚Äôs hand, I could tell she was afraid that her wrinkles had multiplied. 

Sweets came home for both the kids. But one was shown the horror of bad and broken teeth, the other was reminded of diabetes. Rebellion, however, was strong against each cause. 

You know what mothers say to explain their sloppy kisses on your fully grown face, right? A child eternally remains a child for her. But it‚Äôs not the same for us, is it? Mom‚Äôs always mom, but in a jiffy of a few decades, she‚Äôs also the baby. 

Somewhere in the midst of crumpling bills into balls, falling in and out of love, cursing your job, finding your vocation, planning the same trip for the third time this year, it slowly sinks in that times have changed. 

One day you‚Äôll pull her to the other side of the walkway to battle the racing traffic of the city. You‚Äôll rote-learn your own prescription, but set phone reminders for hers. She‚Äôd be watching her favourite show on a rainy morning of July and you‚Äôll bring her a hot roti straight from the kitchen, just like she did for you. 

You‚Äôll delay your trip because she can‚Äôt sleep alone when she‚Äôs sick. You‚Äôll sneak in some chocolates for your cheat days, but they‚Äôd be stashed away in a drawer far from her frail hands. Hands that love those goddamn, beautiful, wrinkles. Wrinkles that hold your childhood. 

And that role-reversal? The most bitter-sweet part of adulthood.


#writer

postContent:
I stand corrected. Your social media reach does matter. 

I have written a total of 50 posts in the past 6 months. Against all rules of LinkedIn, right? If you‚Äôre consistent on a platform, you could write a poem on donkeys and get massive reach.

Then what‚Äôs the point of laying bare your soul for complete strangers? At least that‚Äôs what I thought. I‚Äôve tasted the high of that initial virality.  Loved it, but never enough to chase it. 

A wise woman once told me, and quite angrily so, that you MUST care about your reach. That people hear what you say. That you move the needle even when the meter‚Äôs not in plain sight. 

We don‚Äôt understand how powerful words are until a single quote answers your decade-old question. Until a book wraps you in its yellow pages and pulls you out of a dark place. Until a dialogue from a movie changes your personal misery into a universal experience to bandaid your wound. 

You think you want to be known by thousands and lakhs of followers. But then one night, someone DMs you saying ‚Äúi cried reading your post because i didn‚Äôt know anyone else felt this way‚Äù and you realise what being known really means. Not by many, but by one. Completely. 

Words build bridges. And they burn them too. They make strangers fall in love and best friends fall apart.

I‚Äôve seen people overuse the weight of ‚Äòforever‚Äô and underplay a ‚Äòthank you‚Äô in response to a ‚ÄúI‚Äôm proud of you, kid!‚Äù. I‚Äôve seen them play hide&seek with metaphors and divulge a painful detail cloaked in humour. I‚Äôve seen them weep in words, laugh in words, love in words. People remember you because you made them feel seen when they were hiding. Heard when they were screaming into pillows. Loved when they couldn‚Äôt find it at home. 

Your words did that. Your one little scribbling of a post did that. And your consistency made it reach someone who needed it the most. 

I say chase that reach. You never know who‚Äôs walking taller today because they found your words at the right time. Try not to measure your worth by the outcome, but chase regardless. 

I know I will. And I‚Äôm terribly sorry for gatekeeping what I had to say. Not anymore.

postContent:
Forgiveness is something you choose to give for your own sanity. 

I‚Äôm a quarter past life and I have never met my biological father. But having grown up without one, I can tell you that abandonment issues come to the surface way before you‚Äôve even tucked that term into your word bank. 

You start believing that love is earned in half only when it‚Äôs showered in twofold. There‚Äôs a skin-crawling anxious attachment with a person who romances you beyond their emotional capacity. Would he still love me if he found me sobbing on a Monday morning? What if he learns I‚Äôm not a fan of rock music? ‚ÄúHey Siri, play ‚Äòwhole lotta love‚Äô and make me like it.‚Äù

One would think a man chose not to see his first-born grow into a woman because he‚Äôs demonic like that. Or is it something you can get away with? Or is the guilt of leaving so heavy on their chest that it chokes them from saying anything at all? I‚Äôd never know. 

Last night, I put my earphones on for the first time in a long time and listened to a eulogy from a son to his father. He said, ‚ÄúIt was easier not to forgive him. As long as I was living the life that he had ruined, any mistake I made could be laid at his feet for the childhood that I grew up in.‚Äù 

I felt it right in the gut. Because whether or not he knows, I had forgiven my father ages ago. Not because he was worthy of my forgiveness, not because my beautiful mother overcompensated for the void, not because my grandfather dyed his greys so that he didn‚Äôt look different from the other dads at PTA meetings. 

Because forgiveness is something you choose for your own sanity. Because for as long as I have love, I want to absorb every iota of it without a hint of insecurity. Because why would you expect abandonment from people who do anything but leave your side? 

And so, you choose forgiveness. You choose to live the life you deserve.

postContent:
Do you know what happens right after someone‚Äôs gone?

At first you think the air is heavier than your footsteps. There‚Äôs an eerie silence that bores through the cries. And even in the scorching sun, your immediate ambit is cloudy, it‚Äôs colder. 

But a lengthy minute later, you see the world in a different light and drop your shoulders. You‚Äôll understand the transience of time. You‚Äôll notice that the straightest face is in disbelief while tears trickle down in acceptance. 

He worked his fingers to the bones to bring her every piece of the rainbow, but his wife will pick the most colorless saree from her wardrobe. His father wonders whether he could have lent him a winter of his life. 

What remains of his knowledge is what he passed on in values. In the way his daughter grows another spine to come of age before time, in the way she gulps a cry down her throat to be the stronger one. 

No person in your vicinity who speaks of his title. ‚ÄúHe was kind, he was loving, he always smiled at me.‚Äù You‚Äôll witness a man being reduced to the memories of him. And whether or not he lived a good life, these can still be good memories. 

You‚Äôll see people passively preparing themselves for his absence. Transferring contacts to their phone, wearing their wrist-watch again to be early everywhere. 

There‚Äôs murmur all around. Some concerning grief, some about the 2 carat diamond ring on a certain Mona maasi‚Äôs finger. Faces irrevocably deprived of their glow, faces waiting to clock out of their performance. 

You‚Äôll see what‚Äôs left behind a human is still life- in all its futility. And life, as it‚Äôs always known to do, just goes on. 

So if your ultimate purpose is to build a legacy that can only be signed off or wealth that can only be willed, think again. Life after you will go on with and without the tangibles.

Memories? Thats quite something to leave people with. Be kind, be loving, smile more often, share your time. Live for the intangibles. Live before you can‚Äôt.

author: Shailya Jaggi

postContent:
We‚Äôve lost the plot, haven‚Äôt we? 

Slow and steady wins the race, good things take time, and Rome irrefutably wasn‚Äôt built in a day. But we need everything sooner than now. 

We want to set the playback speed of our lives at 2x, listen to people not in their full cadence but trimmed, compressed, at 1.5x please! 

Let‚Äôs fast-forward conversations while an AI model replicates the stutter in your voice, the pause in your story, the rise and fall of your pitch. 

It‚Äôs reading your books first, and then your prompts, and then your impulsive nerve. You no longer call your husband for a missing ingredient. Cheese is always 10 minutes away. 

Swipe right, and left, and right, and purposely forget that your intent is inversely proportional to the number of choices on dating apps. But why can‚Äôt I get love at the speed of a hookup? 

Do kids still know about plaster of paris? Do they flip the pages of a pocket dictionary to look for a new word? God save me, cocomelon is not a word! 

I wonder what happened to us despite wise men vouchsafing that only fools rush in. And if you made it till the end of this rant, thank you for your patience. The world needs it.

postContent:
I am here to overshare. 

The internet cannot know everything. People do business with strong-headed people. The bouncy-balls. Shock and dejection and failure bounces right off them and they‚Äôre back again in all their glory. 

But me? I grieve in words, I laugh in words. I write on a public platform as if we‚Äôre a big whatsapp group of friends. Over 23,000 people here know that I‚Äôm partly shredded, partly a person. And that I have 13 tattoos, no pets, social anxiety, 500 unread messages, and a little trauma literarily locked away. 

Not a single soul on earth who doesn‚Äôt like to be seen, even when hiding is their second nature. I like to be seen too. The likes, the comments, the DMs, the love, the criticism. None of that attention eludes my pride. I would undoubtedly bring up my 23,000 followers in a conversation with a random stranger. 

Is that the reason why I overshare? Hell to the naw naw. I overshare because I write. I write a lot and I write about everything. For anyone who has ever met me on a Friday evening, they‚Äôd be concerned to learn that I write more than I talk. 

Personal branding left the window a long long time ago. I market myself outside of social media. I do honest work, and an even more honest attempt to get to that opportunity. But here? I just write. 

Because when I do, I earn quite a lot. In a globally aspired currency. I earn silent friendships, loud friendships, a big hug for a small win, a phone-call in dire times from someone I helped a decade ago. A lot more, I‚Äôd say. But I‚Äôve heard it‚Äôs an act of class to keep some of your wealth hidden. 

For anyone who doesn‚Äôt know me - Hi! I am a writer, and I am here to overshare. :)

I‚Äôm writing this with a heavy heart. (trigger warning: suicide, depression) 

It has been over a year since we moved into our new home. A couple of days before our house-warming, we knocked our neighbours‚Äô door to give away hello-donuts. Perhaps a goodwill gesture, more so because we love making friends. 

We never heard again from most of them, but our next-door family reciprocated and how! A 40-something handsome doctor, a brave mom, a dad who was rather shy, and a dog who introduced us to every decapitated toy she owned. 

We got friendly with doc in no time. His turquoise eyes, wide smile, and vocabulary of a conversationalist- all so welcoming. And aunty? She had learnt that we‚Äôd rather have her low-calorie choley bhaturey than aaloo cutlet. 

What we shared was more than a wall. A vocal friendship. My mom would come back from the duty-free with chocolates for both me and doc. And he thought he had to return the gesture, so he brought gifts for the skincare enthusiasts that we are. One of the nicer dermats, this man. 

He had once mentioned about his depressive episode, and then assertively told us that he had gotten better. Of course, with that wide sparkly smile that he had, we believed him. 

But this Monday morning was easily the most scarring of my life. Around 8:30 am, our house-help came rushing to our room and told us that he was gone. I am sure not willingly, but intentionally. I don‚Äôt want to give out many details, but I know that I will never be able to see that 360-degree view of the city from our terrace again. 

It hasn‚Äôt sunk in. It hasn‚Äôt sunk in that he is gone, it hasn‚Äôt sunk in that the last time I saw him, he still had that big smile on his face. It hasn‚Äôt sunk in that he was beyond repair, and still so..normal. 

It has never hit me harder that depression doesn‚Äôt look the same on everyone. And men, especially, feel this constant need to be strong. To be the man. The man who smiles through everything. Even internal demise. 

I don‚Äôt know who has a friend or neighbour or family that needs to hear this. Please, seek help. Being strong is seeking help. Being strong is admitting that you haven‚Äôt been. 

Please, seek help when you need it.

postContent:
My grandfather told me that I was a bird. 

No, not because he wanted me to spread my wings and be the wind beneath them. He, in all seriousness, told me that I was a small bird on their porch who grew into a big little girl. It was a 15-minute theatrical response to the inescapable question of ‚Äúwhere did I come from?‚Äù

I spent most of my childhood with my grandparents, and they had lived more stories than they could read to me from a Champak. Every time I couldn‚Äôt find answers or joy in little things, they told me an elaborate story. 

Sick day? Khichadi dates back to 8th century BCE, a royal culinary wonder that Draupadi would often feed the Pandavas. He‚Äôd serve a generous dollop of Boroline to his skin and tell me about his encounter with Rishi Kapoor at a bar. While of course, I ennnjoyyedd khichadi. 

My life was a storybook, and every day a chapter. That‚Äôs just how powerful storytellers are. When all glitter‚Äôs not gold, they still smear it on everything. World shines. It shines so bright! 

I wasn‚Äôt passed on books or magazines or art or culture. I think they lost touch with education after the 10th board. But I was passed on stories that I remember till date. Stories that would wrap mundane in magic and sit on my tongue for years. 

Seven years of writing and I still can‚Äôt call myself a storyteller. The bar‚Äôs set too high. 

But do yourself a favour and find storytellers. Befriend them, steal their minutes, and if you happen to catch them right after their second drink (of whatever is their age-appropriate beverage), you‚Äôll get lucky. 

P.S ‚ÄúThis toy bounces back every time you hit it hard, and life sometimes treats us like a toy. You‚Äôll hear laughter and bitter words and celebration of your defeat, but you bounce back!‚Äù

postContent:
I keep hitting delete. 

On the post that divulges the tiniest details of my day. 30 reactions in 60 minutes and no hearts? Did it not skip a beat? Does it not say I‚Äôm a writer? What if they never know I am, or what if I‚Äôm seldom seen as one? Delete. 

On the poem that bleeds into the most vulnerable crevices of your existence. Do they know too much? Am I still a girlboss in my toughest hour? Strength is present in the classroom, just not as talkative today. Delete. 

And then on parts of myself that are too boring, too quiet, always at home. Who stays at home on a Friday evening anyway? Three true-crime documentaries in a row doesn‚Äôt say ‚Äúadventurous‚Äù as loud as a karaoke night. Delete. 

People‚Äôs perception of you is cursory. A small glance, a brief frown, a quick scroll, a disapproving nod, a shabby eye-roll. 

You? You‚Äôre here to stay. You‚Äôre here to take space. You‚Äôre here with your neon-pink blazer and your winged eyeliner. You‚Äôre the outcast who doesn‚Äôt like to go out for a loud evening. You like your yellow house. 

You‚Äôre the words that went unnoticed, the poem that got away. Perhaps today you have an audience of 10, with only 20 hands to clap. But they‚Äôre so loud. So, so loud! 

Don‚Äôt hit delete. Take space, let yourself be.

People don‚Äôt have to, but they do. 

He‚Äôll write you a letter while you‚Äôre still asleep at an unholy hour in the afternoon. Tucked under the pillow, hanging by a fridge magnet, on your bedside table.

Magnets! She‚Äôll go on a work trip and buy one for you. You‚Äôve never been to Azerbaijan but it‚Äôll sit on your fridge with the rest of your scouted world. 

Wrinkled fingers will tie a kala-dhaga on your wrist because you looked too pretty in your farewell saree. And someone will gift you a framed picture of that moment on your birthday. 

Flowers are easy to book. Click, schedule, click, pay. But the note will tell you something they‚Äôve never said in their voice. ‚ÄúI love you‚Äù. Ah, I knew it! 

I have something called a keepsakes drawer. Cards from 2006, letters from my first bestfriend, polaroids from a girls‚Äô week out, friendship bands in heaps, dusty photoframes. 

You‚Äôll always leave people behind. You become wiser than them, or dumber. You tread, they run. You love, they fall out of it. There are plenty reasons to let go of people, but none to let go of memories. 

I‚Äôve now replaced the keepsakes drawer with my google drive. Screenshots of messages from you, sob-worthy comments, every little good thing I‚Äôve ever been told is irrevocably stored. 

You see, people don‚Äôt have to, but they do. 
They go an extra mile for you.

postContent:
This was my room for 15 bitter-sweet years. 

Pan the camera to the right and there‚Äôs a wall that touches my bed. To the left is a kitchen with ears, and perhaps is still privy to my teen secrets. 

If you think the bedsheet is forcibly floral, my blanket would give you a garden of nightmares. But this is where I sat, mostly by myself, to dream big. 

I‚Äôd spend my weekly pocket-money to get a cassette loaded with bollywood songs, and dream of a space to dance until the tape was manually rolled out by my pinky finger. 

The first page of my diary read my life goals. A dress from the big mall, a house for my mom, a whole pizza to myself, a trip to anywhere with beaches, or maybe New York because every rom-com opened with ‚ÄòEmpire State of Mind‚Äô. 

The best thing about small rooms is that they always have room for dreams. Big dreams. 

Today, when I look around, nothing seems real. My many-hued rug, a fridge full of things I buy and forget to eat (mostly broccoli), and I‚Äôm not exaggerating when I say that my closet is a mall in itself. 

When people ask me what my big dreams are, I buffer. I am still buffering. The truth is, I am living all of them. There‚Äôs a lot of space in my room, and I‚Äôve run out of songs to dance on. This is all the life I wanted. 

And while it‚Äôs easy to look above and beyond and afar, only to feel that you‚Äôre yet to have more, I look back. I look here. I look at my room from 10 years ago. 

If that little girl knew that the world is her diary and she writes for a living, she‚Äôd dance right there on the bed.
