postContent:
I colossally effed up freelancing in the first few years. And in true LinkedIn fashion, I‚Äôll tell you how.

Another listicle (whattt?)! 

1. I relied solely on references and word-of-mouth, which is a decent boost to self-esteem but you‚Äôre more likely to exhaust this network of leads. Make your presence known on social media, reach out to people, beg for work if you have to. Your talent is not directly proportional to your number of monthly inbound leads. 

2. Try not to chase only high-ticket clients in the first two years. When you oversell as an under-experienced freelancer, you‚Äôll meet the infamous imposter syndrome at every step of the way. Learn, learn, and learn before you put a price tag on your services. 

3. Learning doesn‚Äôt mean being able to deliver. It means being able to deliver, analyse, double down on what‚Äôs working and pivot when a project tanks, people-managing, client relationships, and bringing in some actual ROI. There‚Äôs no shortcut to any of this. 

4. I‚Äôve gone months without work, slept on prospects and proposals, have beautifully underperformed at times. If your health (mind or body) are not in your favour, freelancing is going to be a bumpy ride. Fix your problems before you draw up an invoice to fix someone else‚Äôs. 

5. Get rid of your ego, please. If you started with a niche, called yourself a master/expert/ninja/messiah, and somewhere down the line realised that it‚Äôs not scalable, or not for you - switch! Accept your defeat, change your LinkedIn tagline, get that full-time job, find what else you‚Äôre good at. People will talk about it for a day and move on. 

6. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve worked for 100+ Founders and Entrepreneurs and Zamboni drivers in 2 years‚Äù. When you read this, smirk and scroll past it. If I could tell you the number of people I have been friends with (who you definitely follow here) that blatantly lied about their work, you‚Äôll pay me for the tea. And they‚Äôre talking about retainers ffs. How bad are you that you were able to disappoint a hundred people in 2 years?! Internet is FULL of lies. Focus on your own work. 

7. Have role-models, admire their work, take inspiration, but try not to always follow their lead. It‚Äôs very possible for an experienced person to do it wrong, or perhaps their way is not meant to be your way. If you oppose the cancel-culture, protest the worship-culture too. 

8. Your next obvious step after having tons of leads in your pipeline doesn‚Äôt üëèüèª have üëèüèª toüëèüèª be üëèüèª an üëèüèª agency. Just because every second person you know wants to become a Founder, you don‚Äôt have to shy away from your ambition. Bigger is not always better. If this is not the right time or the right thing for you, be unabashedly lowkey. 


I have 10 more so I‚Äôll do a part two because it‚Äôs a weekend and I need to chill. :)

postContent:
Where do I start? 

If I could count the number of young poets and diary-writers who have asked me this question, I‚Äôll run out of all creases on my fingers. 

I started quite early, perhaps when I stopped googling quotes for a Facebook status and began to write my own. I wrote love essays on my friends‚Äô walls (not the ones fortifying their homes). 

I wrote rhymes, free-verse, sometimes nothing substantial and gave it the title of ‚Äòabstract‚Äô. My first portfolio was made on Google docs a day after chastising my 12th board marksheet. 

I got paid for blogs, articles, FAQs, keyword-research. SEO? I took up a course and learnt what digital marketing was all about.

I took everything that came my way. Dignified work? Sure. Need help for your college essay? Sure. Your baby‚Äôs first birthday invitation card? The quickest yes. 

I would attend college, go back home for client work, record voiceovers over the weekend, and go 35 hours without sleep to shoot the films I had written with people just as curious as I was. 

I wrote erotic, I wrote philosophy, I wrote research papers, I wrote ads, I wrote emails to random strangers on the internet. 

I‚Äôve lost count of the number of odd projects I‚Äôve taken. Some worked, some I completely sucked at. 

But I know exactly why there was so much room for experimentation. This was the time when social media was nothing more than a weekly escape for me. I didn‚Äôt know how better or worse were people of my age doing. 

So I did what I had to. I started everywhere, I found myself somewhere. 

Where should you start? 

Wherever there‚Äôs less noise about how many figures you can earn in a month. Wherever they don‚Äôt have the secret sauce for lead-generation or whatever‚Äôs the new buzzword. 

And if money is the problem, take up a job and start behind-the-scenes. Start with trying to write what you love to read. Just start somewhere right. :)

postContent:
We met 14 years ago. 

Perhaps on Facebook, or was it Orkut? I wasn‚Äôt looking for anything serious, forby I was too young for love. 

Little commitment, more exploration. We would flirt, hold hands, dream, dance..

At first, we only met on rainy days. Those particularly somber evenings when you have to read a pretty poem and recite it to your aching heart. 

And then we began to find each other on the joyous ones. Loneliness was a populated town, and we evaded it with our love. 

But something changed when we performed together on the school stage. I don‚Äôt remember seeing a single pair of hands that didn‚Äôt clap. 

The sparks, the romance, the alchemy. All too evident. 

Something told me that we were end-game. And I must have been audacious to show us the commitment I did. I have my love tattooed on my forearm for God‚Äôs sake! 

It has been 14 years now. We meet in agony, in glee, in laughter, in tears. We‚Äôre late for our date on Mondays, but Sundays are only for us. 

We‚Äôve spent weeks and months without each other, and they‚Äôve always felt like eons, but the spark never dwindles. 

We meet on high-chairs at a dimly lit bar, we meet at the beaches, we meet when nobody‚Äôs around and even more when everybody‚Äôs watching. 

I haven‚Äôt known a better love. 
Me and my words against the world, or maybe just in it. 


P.S I got this tattoo at 18 when I decided I‚Äôd be nothing but a writer (which meant I‚Äôd be a lot at once). The ink‚Äôs old, the design‚Äôs shabby, but it says ‚ÄúI write my own universe‚Äù.

postContent:
We killed art. We killed intellect. We killed innocence. 

We witnessed talent turn latent and applauded Ewtubers for their quick success. We gave medals to the tiktok dancers and trends to performers. 

We scrolled to the doomsday watching people school us on how to look prettier, how to get richer, how to become smarter. 

We liked, shared, subscribed to mediocrity. We witnessed frivolity and crassness and gave it the title of ‚Äòcool‚Äô and ‚Äòauthentic‚Äô and ‚Äòreal‚Äô. Real problem. 

We defended the rebel kids for their unhinged vagaries until we hinged on their absurdity. We brought fame to their lives, insecurities to ours. 

We murdered poets, they‚Äôre all dead in the society. We put our kids on the internet at the cost of their naivety, all for an adult‚Äôs entertainment. 

We buried the written-word, we chopped squat our attention spans. We read more tips and tricks than books and biographies. 

We watched what they ate in a day, what they have in their bags. We ate up the most expensive chunk of our time, we bulked up our emotional baggage. 

We‚Äôll curse them, we‚Äôll curse ourselves. We‚Äôll swear to read good, watch good, hear good. But the truth is, we‚Äôll continue to scroll.

We‚Äôre all culprits. 
Guilty as (un)charged.

postContent:
‚ÄúShaadi kab karni hai?‚Äù 
A question that will grate on you as soon as you touch 25, even sooner if you‚Äôre a woman. 

Having spent a lot of time alone and losing people to the ultimate climax of life, my aspiration was to have a fuller family. The kind of family where weddings are never intimate, because you know over 150 relatives by their names. 

I wanted to have a home, a husband, a kid, another kid for my first, a living room that looks like a night-club on a Diwali evening. In the most quintessential fashion, I wanted a ‚Äòsettled life‚Äô. 

And why shouldn‚Äôt one have that aspiration? Independence and togetherness co-exist, freedom and tradition can work in conjunction. I want whatever‚Äôs in my stars, and connect the dots to make it a goddamn constellation. 

But do you know what a settled life really is? When two or five, the family is full at all times. When you‚Äôve found a living-room big enough for your time of leisure. When you have the emotional bandwidth to love a being, and a healthy body to birth one. 

When you have the choice to have all or none of that. All or none, YOUR CHOICE. 

The best relationship I‚Äôll ever have is with myself, and everything else will be a bigggg heftyyyy bonus. Is that bonus still my aspiration? Hell to the yes. It‚Äôs a choice I want to deliberately and ardently make. 

I want to have a home, a husband, a kid, another kid for my first, a living room that looks like a night club on a Diwali evening. But first, I want a settled life. 

I‚Äôm on it.

Every time I‚Äôve done something after a break, I‚Äôve done it with utter shame. 

When I was in school, I‚Äôd see life on psychedelics after a sick leave. Every teacher‚Äôs wicked smile jeered at my absent note, and their black bindis, a subtle symbolism of my dark future. 

My classmates laughed louder, ridiculed me, they knew I was behind fifteen pages of notes. The school assembly theme was ‚Äòdiscipline is destiny‚Äô, do they know I was missing for a week? 

College? A bigger disaster. I would forget the way to my canteen from my classroom. Was it left, or right, am I still a part of the possie I gained entry to? 

I‚Äôve been missing for far too long to have best friends, or any friends at all. The girl who generously gave me her scrunchie on the first day just walked past. Four days out of sight, forever out of mind. Dumb, Shailya! 

If I don‚Äôt touch my laptop all weekend, I‚Äôll play out a dialogue in my head word by word. The one between my existing client and their new writer. 

Should‚Äôve just taken my laptop to the bar, should‚Äôve picked the call in the third ring. Was I sick for the second time this month? She‚Äôs laden with viruses, more severely with that of incompetence. 

The qualms have steadied with age and experience, the shame has taken a backseat. But the nerves? Still there. Every single time. 

The only place that doesn‚Äôt make me nervous after a break is this one. You all. 

I could disappear for a week and still be welcomed with a ‚ÄúI missed you‚Äù from someone I‚Äôve never met. I get love in the same numbers and magnitude. I am hugged with the same warmth, no questions asked. 

And for that, I‚Äôm grateful beyond words. I‚Äôve broken every possible LinkedIn rule. That of consistency and engagement and visibility. 

But honesty? Never. 
And you‚Äôve appreciated every bit of it selflessly.

Gratitude is the choicest practice. 

I come back home from a lengthy work-trip and smile at my untouched medicine sack. Gratitude. 

My AC‚Äôs set at 25 in scorching summers, while the heater stays on for 3 hours in the nights of January. Gratitude. 

I enter a restaurant without checking my bank balance thrice and eat what was only aspirational for my 14-year-old self. Gratitude. 

I pull one piece of clothing out of my wardrobe and a fabric avalanche erupts on my fluffy chappals. Gratitude. 

I‚Äôve seen mountains, beaches, beaches with the backdrop of mountains, the big five of a jungle. Gratitude. 

I miss at least one meal a day, by choice. Please read that again. I miss one meal a day, by choice. Gratitude. 

I write for the love of it, I write for people, I write for my joy, I write for a living. Gratitude. 

There‚Äôs always something left to achieve. There‚Äôs upwards and onwards and ahead and far. 

So I choose to look within, look around, look at now. Look at home. You look at home. :)

postContent:
I always wanted a man like Raj. 

If not in the middle of a farm with a mandolin, then at my doorstep with flowers. Always ready to love, always ready to rescue me. 

You can‚Äôt blame me now, can you? I have deep daddy issues that I seldom talk about, and I‚Äôve grown up watching movies where men always trudge the extra mile. 

And then I met a man who needed a little more love than I did. He wasn‚Äôt broken, just not familiar with the grandeur of romance. Always a little hesitant, always a little shy. We call it the ‚Äòbare minimum‚Äô at our own convenience. 

Totally capable of building me a garden of flowers, but just didn‚Äôt know when and how to. At first, I was mad. Why am I not being rescued? Why am I the more vehement lover? 

Those godforsaken romantic movies, I tell you. Hugh Grant and Richard Gare spoiled me. They fed me unrealistic dreams. 

I‚Äôm better informed now. I know love is not all fireworks, and relationships are never 50-50. Sometimes the man‚Äôs a 70, and sometimes the woman. 

We can love in our own capacity, and yet abundantly. So who am I to say that I am the more vehement lover, when someone‚Äôs diffident love is their 150%? 

And why should I wait until I find someone whose 100% is as loud, unabashed, and dramatic as mine? Why can I not love more the person I want to love? I‚Äôm strong, I‚Äôm independent, I have degree in romantic gestures. 

What if..I am the Raj? And why doesn‚Äôt he deserve a Raj like me?

postContent:
Comfort zone. 

Waking up on the fifth snooze, working from home for the 3rd week of the month, all cameras off on a zoom call. 

Doing the known, talking to the familiar. Sauce pans are heavier than paper bags, and we no longer saut√©, we have it all sorted. 10 mins away, just blink it. 

We want our kind of coffee on our side of the bed, pillows fluffed, books half-read, diaries painted with griffonage. Maps should drop me off at the doorstep of a cafe. 

You know what‚Äôs the worst part about your comfort zone? It makes you too comfortable. No plot-twists, no fears, no hikes, nothing to conquer today. 

Last month, all I did was step out of my comfort zone. 

I worked for 12 hour a day for seven days a week. 
I booked a flight 6 hours before I was supposed to catch it. 
I cooked two meals of my day; always ordered the last. 
I read fiction, it was all vague and all consumed. 
I talked to unfamiliar faces, went to unknown places. 
I took up the projects I‚Äôm not a ninja-master at. 
I stepped away from social media, I became more social. 
I wrote on the hardest day of writing; you‚Äôre reading it now. 

No, I‚Äôm not saying that I‚Äôll push myself out of my comfort zone every day. I want to live more, not barely. 

But man-o-man, the comfort zone! It needs to be shown its place every once in a while.

postContent:
I think it all began when I was 12. 
I would wake up before my morning alarm. 
Take a shower, let half my tresses air-dry, and then came the straightening wand. 
Wet hair sandwiched between a ssssssound, which was always more bearable than my lousy curls.

By 14, I was a fully grown woman.
I bled more blood than my body could make, 
So my lips were always pale, grey, ashy. Nothing like a woman‚Äôs lips in poems. 
Slathered a nivea tinted lipbalm, a fortune above my pocket-money, but still more affordable than my weary appeal. 

At 17, the greater part of my closet was black.
I handpicked darkness, because it is meant to make your waist look small. Tiny. Petite. Worthy of an embrace. 
Starved myself a day before the famous girl‚Äôs birthday party, but still fuller in confidence than on days I ate well. 

At 20, I read more non-fiction than ever. 
I would keep my paradoxes and thrillers on the bottom shelf. Women are beautiful AND smart. 
Witty, well-learned, well-spoken, well-mannered. 
Watched the movies I didn‚Äôt like, but was still more entertained than I was with my own character. 

Now that I am 25, 
I color my hair every year in a different shade of brown, and fix them only on Saturdays. 
I go for morning walks straight out of bed. Bare lips, lousy waves, pimple patches from a night before. 
I wear pink, blue, orange, sssssilver, golden, parrot-green, all-coloured prints. 
I read stories, I live stories, I write stories. 

I write stories.

postContent:
Where do you look for inspiration? 

I‚Äôve turned pages after pages until they turned yellow. I‚Äôve met strong women, independent women, soft women, proud women, confident women. 

And then there‚Äôs this one. She‚Äôs Parveen. 

Parveen takes care of a sizeable family. Two daughters, one newly married. A son who likes his hoodies fresh. A husband who is the biological father to one, step to the others. 

We‚Äôve lustily suggested a small vacation to her, but she‚Äôs always on duty. From one home to another, her scope of work is more agile than what my contracts read. 

If today she‚Äôs having trouble with her landlord, tomorrow she‚Äôll aggressively calculate her son‚Äôs school fee. And mind you, before I met her, I thought my math was the most bizarre. 

I wouldn‚Äôt say she‚Äôs the only woman I‚Äôve seen grappling with the hurlies and burlies of life. But I‚Äôll tell you what fascinates me. 

Her smile. Her laughter. Her curiosity. Her intelligence. Her kindness. Her love. 

She could be having the worst day possible, but she‚Äôll gracefully knock my door to ask me why my lunch‚Äôs still sitting in the kitchen unattended. She jumps at an opportunity to learn a little more about her humble cellphone. 

When people are late to pay her, she would barely ever raise her voice. But, she‚Äôll pose a question that would strike your bone (if the heart has one). ‚ÄúWhy would someone, living in a big house, not pay a timely fee so that I can run my small house?‚Äù 

Sunny or cloudy, work or leisure, misery or glee - this woman smiles. 

She‚Äôs not our house-help. She‚Äôs our house manager. And God knows what I‚Äôd do without her. I‚Äôd cry in a corner and won‚Äôt stop until an external force hits me with happiness. Newton‚Äôs first law of emotion. 

I don‚Äôt smile on all days. But looking at her, sometimes, just sometimes, I want to.

postContent:
I‚Äôm turning 25 tomorrow and (erratic drumrolls) listicles are par for the course with LinkedIn. 

Let‚Äôs do a solid 15 (peut √™tre?)! 

1. An obsession with independence can be self-inflicted misery. Dependency in moderation is a beautiful thing. Make friends, find love, go home. Humans don‚Äôt thrive as lone creatures. 

2. Passionate people will make you pity yourselves. If you had to drop yours for survival, chase it for pleasure. It‚Äôs a privilege to make it your vocation, it‚Äôs stupidity to surrender altogether. 

3. Comparison is inevitable. But next time you want someone‚Äôs life, make a list of things they gave up to achieve it. If these items are your non-negotiables, kick jealousy out. 

4. Nobody‚Äôs looking. Nobody remembers your fumbled words and wrinkled shirts. Don‚Äôt drop your self-esteem for that flash of a second someone takes notice of you. 

5. My world-view at 25 is not going to be the same as that at 35. Don‚Äôt be stubborn with your learnings. Change of heart, mind, and opinions. All beautiful things. 

6. One should have enough money to take themselves out of an unpleasant relationship, and enough self-love to enjoy a bus-ride alone. 

7. If you‚Äôre not happy with what you do, you won‚Äôt be happy with how you look. It‚Äôs not the weighing scale or your nose that you hate. It‚Äôs the lack of movement and procrastination that you despise. 

8. You‚Äôre not wiser than the next person you meet. See what you can take from people than measure how better or worse you are. None beneath or above, all come with lessons. 

9. You can wear modest clothes, hide your selfies, reject designer bags, skip makeup, write poetry, quit drinking without making someone else look bad. Choices don‚Äôt compete. 

10. Love will always escape you if you‚Äôre desperately looking for it. The universe will smell your desire and do everything to make you love yourself first. You‚Äôd rather start there. 

11. Disagree but with logic, with poise, with calm. Never to prove yourself right but to shed light on facts and myths, just and unjust. You‚Äôre not fighting a fight with the whole world. 

12. Ambition is not always position, influence, or wealth. It could be noble, slow, more often hidden from a scrollable social media feed. Don‚Äôt underplay it.

13. The more lies you tell people on the internet, the more lies you start believing about yourself. Praises will be louder than that inner voice telling you to improve. It‚Äôs sweet self-destruction. 

14. Faking success is bad, but faking emotional intelligence is degeneration! Admit it when you realise you don‚Äôt know better, and ask for help. Seeming mature isn‚Äôt better than wetting pillows at night. 

15. Nothing, absolutely nothing tastes better than how healthy feels. It‚Äôs a lone battle for the sharp mind to fight with a feeble body. 

16. Just when you think you can do one more shot before the night ends, just don‚Äôt. Save your gut, remember your night, mind your step. Just don‚Äôt do that last shot.

postContent:
I‚Äôve never spoken about him. It‚Äôs a heavy cross to bear. 

He is..mama. 
If my grandfather took the role of my father, my mama (uncle) was my bro, my pal, my buddy. 

His body was ridden with Parkinson‚Äôs, a disease that slows down your corporeal functions to a fast-paced demise. 

His brain had a condition of its own, as if it wanted to compete with his body. Though a 45 year old, he couldn‚Äôt get wiser than a pre-teen. 

And since I was the youngest in the house, we were pals, bros, buddies. We shared candies, kites, knick knacks from the weekly rummage sale. He had a thing for rings and wallets. 

We shared everything but blue-lays. I‚Äôm not sure why, but I always hid that deep-fried, spice-laden, curse of a snack from him. Greed, I tell you. 

I was growing up, beyond years on most days, but with my age on others. The older I got, the younger and feebler he looked. Body of a 70 year old at 45, but brain stuck at 15. 

And one day, just like that, he was gone. 
I found myself outside a ‚Äòshamshaan ghaat‚Äô in my hometown, the forbidden ground for young women as superstition says. 

It wasn‚Äôt my first meeting with loss. And man, what a big fat lie, this life! We are convinced of its grandeur when only love and kindness are for keeps past the forbidden grounds. 

He was all love and kindness. It‚Äôs everything he left me with. That and a few regrets.

I wish I had flown more kites with him. 
I wish I got him more rings and wallets.
I wish I had shared that damned blue lays. 

Whoever said time is money is a fool. Money may come back, but time? Time will keep you wishing. You‚Äôd rather fight the world to share your time with those who matter. 

Call them, tell them you love them and be awfully loud, buy more wallets or rings or whatever makes their toes tap. 

Do yourself a favour and share your time.

My mother single-handedly took care of our family, and only Lord of the Bearings knows how! 

For the initial 14 years of my life, she was slightly busy building the home we have now after all these years. But, she was never absent. 

If I sit her down to tell her what she did for me, you‚Äôll see the working-mom guilt crawling up her veins. 

It‚Äôs her birthday today, and I could have penned this on a crisp paper. But since she hits refresh on my feed every day, I‚Äôm sure she‚Äôll read it. 

You got me my first ever princess-themed school bag. 
You told me I was invincible when I fell off my three-wheeled bicycle. 
You pulled off a John Galliano on my costume for the first annual function dance. 
You sat in the front row, grinning wide, when I became the cultural minister of my school. 
You drew flags (upside down), moustaches, and whiskers on my face for theatrics. 
You got me my first roller skates, those with pink buckles on them. 
You gave me a tender lecture on choices when a guy broke my heart for the first time. 
You got me the QWERTY of my dreams, took trips to the cyber cafe but placed a CPU on my desk. 
You could miss the world‚Äôs most important affairs but never a PTA meeting.
You never dropped your smile after perusing a report-card. 
You bought me an activa and spent eight long evenings teaching me how to ride it. 
You filled my wardrobe. With clothes warm, clothes absurd, clothes colorful. 
You took me on a no-budget shopping spree before my prom. I picked the most beautiful dress I had ever seen. 
You believed in me when I gave you the crazy idea of me being a writer, you still do. 

You were there. You were present. You didn‚Äôt miss out. While kids went gaga over the supers and irons of men, I watched you. My hero. 

Happy birthday, mom.

Who exactly is a pick-me girl? 

And who hasn‚Äôt ever been? I can tell you all about my foiled tries. I would wear the thickest layer of mystery and stare into eyes with a poker face. 

I didn‚Äôt love pink, but I pretended to loathe pink. The color was too bright, too in-your-face, too girly. How does a forewoman of spine wear pink without shame?! 

I shook my head from side to side in disapproval of a certain vodka, because whiskey is a man‚Äôs drink. And the woman who can down a man‚Äôs drink is a stronger woman. 

Partly because I wanted to be likeable, and partly because I grew up too soon. I was competing not just for attention, but with a world years ahead of me. 

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs different, she‚Äôs intellectual. She reads non-fiction and wears a blazer on Fridays. She‚Äôs not like other girls, you know..‚Äù 

Well, too bad! I am exactly like other girls. Headstrong, heart on my sleeves, fingers dripping gold in love, kindness on the lips. I‚Äôm so much like her. 

Nobody picks you, woman. You pick and choose your life. Lay it on a work-desk, decorate it in your catharsis-corner, take it to your boardroom meetings. YOU PICK AND CHOOSE YOUR LIFE. 

Now I meet people with a smile so big that my face hurts. I don‚Äôt wear a modicum of mystery. Whatever there is to be known about me, is made known. 

Now it‚Äôs me and my pink things against the world.

Despite a pool of evidence, if a woman had to face the defendants, waive her right to anonymity, and play horrific videos in the courthouse..

Would you still believe me if I said many of us take a long time to just process that we were violated? 

Gisele was on sale for over a decade, on an app called √† son insu. Translation? Without her knowledge. WITHOUT HER KNOWLEDGE. 

A 44 year old supermarket worker, father of three.

A 27 year old solider, who revealed in the trial that he missed his daughter‚Äôs birth because he was committing a heinous crime. 

The list is long. She stood in the courthouse nodding her head to every name as the verdicts were announced. 3 years in jail, 5 years in jail, 15 years in jail - for scarring women infinitely. 

This fight is going to be as long as we make it.

He enters his first big corporate party and people are swaying to Pink Floyd. Someone takes notice of his pursed lips, his motionless body, and says, ‚Äúhow do you not know this song?‚Äù 

She found a semblance of friendship in what they call the city of dreams. That artsy cafe has a pool table in the back. Everyone wants to play before the food arrives. To dodge the ignominy of not knowing the game, she mumbles, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll just watch.‚Äù 

He brought home the second TV that he deserved, because the first had played daily soaps and news channels on repeat for a decade. Something for mom, something for dad, nothing for him. Now he has learnt to not mind the look he gets when he reveals how inaccessible was Harry Potter to him. 

We don‚Äôt acknowledge the small privileges, do we? The privilege of information, the privilege of cultural education, the privilege of having parents who read and pass on their treasure of books, the privilege of having pop-culture on our fingertips. 

One would think kindness is giving. Do you know what else is kindness? Involving. 

Next time you meet someone who has never heard a classic song, play something to their taste. 

Next time you meet someone who feels out of place, show them just how clumsy you are with your cues. 

Next time you meet someone who has never watched your favourite movie, tell them how you wish you could see it for the first time again, and they get to. 

Make people feel involved. There‚Äôs already enough FOMO in this world.

postContent:
The whole fuss about ‚Äòfinding your voice‚Äô is not as tricky as it seems. 

It almost always starts with imitation. You read something you like so much that it hurts to not have penned it before a Dostoevsky did. 

You pick songs, you pick words. You string words together, you make songs. You look for the sweetest sounding synonym for a stale (a synonym for boring) word. 

You realise that on one sombre evening with an unsociable friend, when you run out of tonic for your gin, it makes more sense to say ‚Äòboring‚Äô than ‚Äòstale‚Äô. 

You say big words in small poems. You find a lesser-known writer on the internet, drool over their turn of phrase, wonder when it‚Äôll be your turn to become the writer you want to be. 

I‚Äôve done this for almost a decade before I found ‚Äòmy voice‚Äô. And, what was it? What was my voice? How is it mine when I have learnt from what I have read?

The words you savour decide how you write, but the life you live decides what you write. 

And the ‚Äòwhat‚Äô is what makes you unique. The ‚Äòwhat‚Äô comes from a small chat with your heroes, a hike with strangers, a coffee with a filthy rich man who is underdressed for a party. 

It comes from friendships, from love. From how you treat a junior at work, from whoever you extend your helping hand to. It comes from the kirana store uncle who quietly writes shayaris on the last page of his diaries. 

Mind you, the ‚Äòwhat‚Äô evolves with time and age and places. So does your writing. Evolution and growth are beautiful to witness. Caterpillars are as wondrous as butterflies. 

Be envious, be aspirational. But don‚Äôt try to copy at 25 what you read from a writer in his 50s. When one tries to achieve what they haven‚Äôt lived, they grow more doubts than creativity. 

Your voice is what you are NOW. In this very moment.

You‚Äôre a coward. A big, big coward. 

You‚Äôre freakishly punctual, but you tactfully arrive late at the bar so that you don‚Äôt have to sit with your drink alone. 

You fear going to unfamiliar places, because you don‚Äôt have the muscle memory of the rights and lefts it takes to reach the door. 

Ordering for one on a table for two terrifies you, so you pick something bite-sized. Something quick. 

You‚Äôd parch yourself to suffocation but wouldn‚Äôt dare to touch the vending machine, because what if you‚Äôre fool enough to never figure out how to get that water bottle? 

You keep your fingers crossed before you step into an elevator, and try not to breathe heavy if there‚Äôs company. 

Do they hear that I‚Äôm breathing heavy? Am I taking too much space? 

And you just can‚Äôt be found on a street doing..nothing?! You‚Äôll fiddle with your phone, pretend to message your friend, perhaps even reply to a friend on that one particularly annoying whatsapp group. 

Does the airport security know it‚Äôs only my second time on an international flight? Of course they know! Look how shabbily you placed your luggage on the conveyer belt. Noob. 

We don‚Äôt talk much about it, do we? About that godawful social anxiety that keeps you from living experiences of a lifetime. If only we talked more about it, you‚Äôd know. 

You‚Äôd know that you‚Äôre not a coward, you‚Äôre not timid, you‚Äôre not under scrutiny. You‚Äôd think that it gets better as you grow older, but you only get better as you grow fonder. 

Fonder of yourself.

postContent:
You know when you‚Äôre in your mid 20s and your birthday becomes just another day?

This picture is from my first ever birthday, and I reckon it looks like a happy one. Smile so wide, you can barely see the twinkle in my eyes. 

I often speak about being a loved child. I was my grandparents‚Äô second chance at having their first daughter. I was my mother‚Äôs universe. My uncle came to blows with the world every other day to protect my twinkle. 

But the day of my birth was all but rosy. Heck, I‚Äôd say it looked like a crime scene. My mother, a felon for bringing home a girl-child. You‚Äôd wonder why the year 2000 was lagging. Unfortunately, a small town is a decade behind metro cities. 

She was in an abusive, precarious marriage. And to make it worse, she had just popped out a girl for a Brahmin family in the smallest corner of Uttarkashi. Felon, she!

My first cry wasn‚Äôt my cry alone. Everybody in the labour room weeped. My father refused to celebrate. My paternal aunt, however, was kind enough to embrace a 23-year young mother and bring the tiniest dabba of besan ke laddoo for the hospital staff. 

I believe that was the day when my mother decided that she could compromise on a married life, but not on the life she had just created. A couple of months passed before she walked out. Took the blue pram that she had revolted for and never looked back. 

A young mother, in the middle of a divorce, in a backward society, with little to no money and far from a job- she wanted to celebrate my first birthday. Oof, the strength! If I had half of it, I would have been a pretty big deal today.

She could afford only four big balloons, a make-shift cake, and a kodak film that developed twenty negatives at a time. It was a party of three. My mother, my grandmother, and an absolutely clueless but very jolly Shailya. 

Ever since that day, I‚Äôve been told that I am a blessing. Owing to the position of women in the society, my mother was titled ‚Äòghar ka beta‚Äô. And me? I was then, and am, the very loved ‚Äòghar ki beti‚Äô. 

My birthday is 40 days away, and I am beyond excited for it. If my creator had the heart and gall to celebrate me in the darkest of days, how dare I?! 

How dare I treat my birthday like it‚Äôs just another day?

postContent:
I don‚Äôt need a man. 

Says a woman who always storms into rooms, never glides. Dressed to the nines, the posture of an Aphrodite, a jading smile, world on her shoulders. 

The narrative is a winner. When Pussycat Dolls said ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need a man‚Äù, a whole generation of women felt empowered. The idea was to remind us that we don‚Äôt NEED a man, and they don‚Äôt come wearing the key to your happiness around their necks. 

But what about..wanting a man? Does it make you a fragile woman? Incomplete? Dressed down, hunched back, overwhelming grin, in a world far beyond the reach of your delicate hands? 

Yesterday when a girlfriend expressed her strong desire to get married now that she‚Äôs 29, another friend acknowledged her and said, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need a man!‚Äù. Almost dismissing her fairytale, she made her feel like love and dependence were beneath her.

I‚Äôve been raised by a mother who also played the role of a father, became the sole bread-winner of the family. Generational wealth of a woman, this one. Having her in the next room every day since the age of 14, I can tell you that I know a lot about not NEEDING a man. 

What you NEED is health, a sound mind, enough money to survive and then to live some, and Woolf would insist on a room of one‚Äôs own. But if you want a man, do not let anyone tell you that you‚Äôre not as strong and independent.

Ah, God knows I want a man! I‚Äôve seen what he brings home. I‚Äôve seen him work round the clock to build a home for his woman. I‚Äôve seen girl-dads and weeping grooms and that one lost boyfriend in a superstore struggling to tell a pad from a tampon. I have no reason to not want a man. 

One thing I have realised after hearing a gazillion stories is that love is a matter of luck. Some find it early, some never do. Some lose it midway, some take it to their grave. 

Keeping that in mind, you should know that you don‚Äôt NEED. 
But if you WANT, I wish you a fairytale.

postContent:
If could meet my younger self, I‚Äôd tell her nothing. Nothing. 

I may be tempted to warn her about a particular doll-faced boy, 
but I‚Äôd let her learn what‚Äôs not love. 

I‚Äôd let silence sit on her mouth while a bully mocks her innocence, 
so that her sock-knocking self thrives but in kindness. 

I‚Äôd let her straighten her hair every morning for school, 
before the bounce in her walk can compete with that in her curls. 

I‚Äôd let her hate her body, make black her favourite color, eat lipsticks in her weight, 
until she learns how to smile at her beauty with her bare lips. 

I‚Äôd let her sit on her pen and find her sword in this haystack of a world, 
so that when she meets her craft, she knows what to owe her life to. 

I‚Äôd let her say something stupid on stage and fumble in an interview, 
I‚Äôd let her cry, fail, stumble, mourn, cheat, lay next to hopelessness in bed. 

I‚Äôd let her make cards for people who‚Äôll later break her a little,
I‚Äôd let her make the same mistake again so that there‚Äôs never a third time. 

I‚Äôd let her miss a call from someone she‚Äôs never going to see again, 
so that she knows just how out of her control life is, and why you should take some calls in a heartbeat. 

And oh would I desperately want to whisper in her ear that she‚Äôll solve half her problems if she

It took me years to realise what home is. 
For the longest time, I thought home is familiarity. Muscle memory. 
When you‚Äôve learned about the best spot to hide your keys under. 
You know exactly how many turns and pushes it takes to unlock the door. 
You know which broken cupboard takes tenderness before it comes tumbling down on your head. 
You know your favourite corner, where your favourite beverage changes from tea to cucumber-flavoured water. 
You know which particular light to turn on a good day. You know the chairs that catch the most dust. 

And one day, you pack all of it in cardboard boxes and move out. Keys packed in an envelope. Cupboards left uncovered. 

Temporary homes are still homes. 
But last year, when we moved into our first permanent home, I understood what a home really is. 
It‚Äôs your state of mind, your healing heart, your recovering self-esteem, your dwindling insecurities. 
It‚Äôs acceptance. Of change, the transience of joy and sorrow, the stillness of your being that is usually accompanied by frequent back aches. 

Every year since 2018, my mother and I would pack our bags on Diwali. 
As our family kept getting smaller, festivals felt lonelier. 
So we‚Äôd take off to Amritsar and celebrate with thousands and thousands of people at the Golden Temple. 
But this time, we‚Äôve decided to stay home. Not because it‚Äôs permanent. 
Because we‚Äôre in a better place. Our heart is as lit up as the city. 
We‚Äôre enough. 

This time, 
We‚Äôll put fairly lights in the balcony.
We‚Äôll light diyas at the doorstep. 
We‚Äôll lay a rangoli in the living room. 
We‚Äôll keep our windows open for all the Gods and Goddesses in the world. 

We‚Äôll be at home.
